Two=20\npossible options for addressing the credit issue are 1) a California PUC=20\norder clarifying that DWR will recover its power purchase costs through=20\nrates, and 2) an amendment to AB1X designed to accomplish the same goal.  I=\n=20\nhave attached talking points regarding the California PUC order and propose=\nd=20\namendments to AB1X.  We believe that an amendment to AB1X is the preferable=\n=20\noption.\n\nOur assessment of the supply/demand picture in California.\n\nOur suggestions for a legislative package designed to solve both the near-=\n=20\nand long-term electricity crisis in California.  We will deliver to your=20\noffice today detailed legislative language.  In those materials we will als=\no=20\nidentify existing bills that we believe can easily accommodate our proposed=\n=20\nlanguage.\n\nI hope that the information is useful.  Please do not hesitate to contact m=\ne=20\nif you would like to discuss these materials further, or if there is anythi=\nng=20\nelse that I can do to assist you.\n\nRegards,\nKen Lay\n\n\n\nContact Information to Discuss Interest Expressed by Native American Tribes=\n=20\nin Installing Small-scale Generation on Tribal Lands\n\nDavid Parquet, Vice-President\nEnron North America\n101 California Street, Suite 1950\nSan Francisco, CA 94111\nPhone: 415.782.7820\nFax: 415.782.7851\n\n\n2. Key Barriers to Distributed Generation\n\nExcessive and Unnecessary Utility Stand-by Charges\n\nSolution: The executive orders issued by the Governor on February 14th took=\n a=20\nstep in the right direction.  Utility stand-by charges have always been=20\ndesigned by the utilities to protect their monopoly position, extract=20\nmonopoly prices from customers, or both.  But there is no reason to limit t=\nhe=20\nelimination of these charges to generation facilities that are less than=20\n1MW.  These limits will only lengthen unnecessarily the time it takes for=\n=20\nCalifornia to close the significant gap between supply and demand and reduc=\ne=20\nthe risk of black outs this summer.  We would propose lifting the cap by=20\noffering amendments to SB27X, which is designed to facilitate development o=\nf=20\ndistributed generation.\n=20\nExcessive delays and costs related to interconnecting facilities with=20\ninvestor-owned and municipal utilities\n\nSolution:   The Governor=01,s executive order regarding interconnection is =\na=20\nstep in the right direction=01*D-D-26-01 requires utilities to complete=20\ninterconnection studies within 7 days.  California should ensure that this=\n=20\nrequirement applies to all generation facilities, including distributed=20\ngeneration.  In addition, the financial conflicts the utilities face when=\n=20\ninterconnecting generation facilities are simply too powerful to overcome=\n=20\nthrough executive orders or other regulations.  To the greatest extent=20\npossible, California should shift control over interconnection away from th=\ne=20\nutility and place that control with the California ISO.  This could be=20\naccomplished through amendments to SB 27X.\n\nPermitting and Air Quality Issues\nDevelopers of distributed (i.e., =01&on-site=018) generation that is 50 MWs=\n or=20\ngreater must receive certification from the California Energy Commission an=\nd=20\ntherefore face all of the impediments to development that large-scale=20\ngeneration faces. =20\n\nSolution: California should ensure that the executive orders (D-22-01 thru=\n=20\nD-26-01) issued by the Governor to expedite plant siting and maximize plant=\n=20\noutput apply equally to smaller scale, =01&distributed generation=018 facil=\nities.=20\nIn addition, distributed generation that is less than 50 MWs continues to=\n=20\nface local opposition.  The State should ensure that local, parochial=20\ninterests cannot block otherwise beneficial distributed generation projects=\n. =20\nThese objectives could be accomplished through amendments to SB27X.\n\n3. Credit Concerns Regarding Authority Granted to DWR in AB1X to Purchase=\n=20\nElectricity on Behalf of the Utilities=20\n\nEnron responded to the RFP issued by DWR to enter into power contracts with=\n=20\nsuppliers.\nEnron is in active discussions with DWR to establish contract terms with th=\ne=20\ngoal of entering into a power purchase agreement as soon as possible.\nHowever, ambiguities contained in AB1X have created significant credit risk=\n=20\nconcerns that need to be resolved in order to finalize contract terms.\nWe understand that the lion=01,s share of counterparties share Enron=01,s c=\nredit=20\nrisk concerns.\nEnron has proposed several options for resolving the credit risk issues and=\n=20\nis working with DWR to arrive at a solution that is mutually agreeable to=\n=20\nboth sides and that might serve as a template for power purchase agreements=\n=20\ngoing forward.\n\nSummary of the Source of the Credit Risk Issue\n\nAmbiguous Ratemaking Authority\nThe language in AB1X is ambiguous as to whether DWR has any authority to=20\ncharge California ratepayers for the costs of purchasing power.  From our=\n=20\nanalysis of the bill, the language in AB1X appears to leave intact the=20\nCalifornia PUC=01,s exclusive jurisdiction over ratemaking in California.  =\nAs=20\nsuch, suppliers have no assurance that the PUC will agree to include in rat=\nes=20\nadequate charges to cover DWR=01,s costs of power purchases.\n\nAmbiguous Regulatory Authority Regarding Contract =01&Prudence=018\nThe language in AB1X leaves open the possibility that the California Public=\n=20\nUtilities Commission could determine that power purchases made by DWR are=\n=20\n=01&imprudent.=018  On the basis of such a finding, the CPUC could then ref=\nuse to=20\nallow DWR to collect from ratepayers the costs associated with its power=20\npurchases.  Consequently, suppliers have no assurance that the PUC will agr=\nee=20\nto include in rates the charges to cover the costs of power contracts that=\n=20\nDWR has entered into with suppliers.\n=20\nAmbiguous Language Regarding the Ratemaking Mechanism that Will Be Used to=\n=20\nRecover DWR=01,s Costs of Power Purchases\nIn addition to the ambiguity regarding ratemaking and regulatory authority=\n=20\nnoted above, the language in the bill is equally ambiguous with respect to=\n=20\nthe specific ratemaking =01&mechanics=018 that AB1X directs the PUC to empl=\noy to=20\npermit DWR to recover its power purchase costs. Based on our analysis, it i=\ns=20\nextremely difficult to determine how the PUC would design the rates to ensu=\nre=20\nDWR recovers its power purchase costs.  Moreover, as currently drafted, it =\nis=20\ndifficult to determine whether AB1X would even permit the PUC to include in=\n=20\nrates all of the charges necessary to fully recover DWR=01,s power purchase=\n=20\ncosts.  Again, this ambiguity raises significant credit risk concerns since=\n=20\nsuppliers have little assurance that DWR will have the ability to recover=\n=20\nfrom ratepayers the costs of purchasing power.\n\nOptions to Resolve Concerns Regarding Credit Risk=20\n\nWe have been working diligently with DWR officials to resolve the credit ri=\nsk=20\nissues.  We have identified three options:\n\nAmend AB1X\nThe amendments, which are attached to this email, would clarify that a) the=\n=20\nPUC would accept as =01&prudent and reasonable=018 all purchase costs incur=\nred by=20\nDWR, and b) the PUC is obligated to include in rates the charges necessary =\nto=20\nensure that DWR fully recovers its costs of power purchases.  This is the=\n=20\npreferred option, though we understand that the there may be some political=\n=20\nchallenges standing in the way of amending AB1X.  (See attached file=20\nentitled, =01&AmendAB1X.doc=018.)\n\nClarify the Ambiguities in AB1X through an Order Issued by the PUC, and=20\nthrough Contract Language\nThis is the option that we are currently working with DWR officials to=20\nimplement.  However, it is more complicated and could take significantly mo=\nre=20\ntime to implement than the "legislative" fix.  We have attached electronic=\n=20\ncopies of the talking points related to the order that the California PUC=\n=20\nwould need to issue under this option.  (See attached file entitled,=20\n=01&cpuctalkingpoints.doc.=018)\n\nMake Use of Other Instruments Designed to Address Credit Risk\nAs indicated in our letter responding to DWR=01,s RFP, we are willing to ac=\ncept=20\nother forms of credit from DWR.  Those options include a letter of credit,=\n=20\ncash prepayment, or an acceptable form of collateral.  DWR officials have=\n=20\nindicated to us that DWR prefers to pursue the second options. That is, DWR=\n=20\nprefers to clarify the ambiguities in AB1X through a PUC order and through=\n=20\ncontract amendments.\n\n4. California=01,s Supply-demand Picture Heading into Summer 2001\n\nBoth the California Energy Commission and Cambridge Energy Research=20\nAssociates (CERA), a private sector energy think tank, have issued reports=\n=20\nshowing that California faces a severe supply-demand imbalance.  They diffe=\nr=20\nonly on how much and how soon additional supply will be made available.  Al=\nl=20\ncredible sources agree that supply will be very tight throughout the Summer=\n=20\nof 2001 and that unless a solution is found immediately, blackouts are=20\nlikely. =20\n\nCEC and CERA both forecast that California will be short of supply this=20\nsummer by approximately 5,000 MW.   These numbers are in line with our=20\nestimates.  California=01,s supply base currently has a 6% capacity margin,=\n well=20\nbelow the average 15-20%, which is recommended for reliable system operatio=\nn=20\nin the West.  Since the West relies more heavily upon hydroelectric power=\n=20\nthan other regions, reserves are particularly important, owing to the=20\nunpredictability of the weather and the dry year the West has experienced t=\no=20\ndate. In the event of a low rain and snow period, the system must possess t=\nhe=20\nflexibility to respond to the reduced availability of power supply. =20\nCalifornia=01,s very low reserve margin makes it especially susceptible to =\nthis=20\nrequirement. =20\n\nOther reasons for reduced supply for the Summer of 2001 include the early=\n=20\ndraw-down of reservoirs in the continual effort to manage California\'s seve=\nre=20\nsupply-demand gap; emissions restrictions on existing plants; and a reduced=\n=20\nnumber of customers who can be curtailed under their contracts with the=20\nutilities.  Cambridge Energy Research Associates asserts that at the curren=\nt=20\npace of siting, permitting and construction, adequate supplies will not be=\n=20\nadded to correct the market imbalance until 2003 at the earliest.\n\nCERA predicts that California is likely to face approximately 20 hours of=\n=20\nrolling black outs this summer.  The CEC paints a considerably more=20\noptimistic scenario, betting that California will bring an additional 5,000=\n=20\nMWs on line to meet peaking summer demand.  It is our view that California=\n=20\nshould view the CEC\'s "rosy scenario" with considerable skepticism.\n\n5. Suggested Package of Legislative Proposals Designed to Solve California=\n=01,s=20\nElectricity Crisis\n\nThis email offers an overview of our proposed legislative solution.  We wil=\nl=20\ndeliver to your office tomorrow specific legislative language and existing=\n=20\nbills that we believe can accommodate our proposals.\n\nAs we have suggested throughout the crisis, any solution to California\'s=20\ncrisis must focus on four issues:\n\nIncrease supply\nDecrease demand\nEstablish a truly competitive retail electricity market\nReturn California=01,s Investor-owned utilities to solvency\n\nIncrease supply--Legislative vehicle: SB28X (Sher)\nTo site and construct a power plant in Texas takes approximately 2 years. =\n=20\nEnron and others have completed the entire process in other states in less=\n=20\nthan a year.  In California, it takes about six years, or longer.\n\nThe Governor=01,s executive orders and Senator Sher=01,s siting reform legi=\nslation=20\nare steps in the right direction.  Our suggested amendments can improve tho=\nse=20\nefforts by further addressing the difficulties that project developers face=\n=20\nin securing air emission reduction credits to meet the air permit=20\nrequirements included in the CEC\'s certification requirements.  Enron=01,s=\n=20\nproposal seeks to streamline the process for 1) obtaining credits and 2)=20\ntransfering credits between air districts.  In addition, it creates an=20\ninnovative emissions reduction bank to allow project sponsors to fund=20\nemissions in advance of obtaining certification, and permits the affected a=\nir=20\ndistricts to use those funds to finance projects that will produce the=20\nrequired reductions in pollution emissions.\n\nDecrease demand=01*Legislative Vehicle:   AB31X (Wright)\nBecause of the delay in getting a solution in place in California, closing=\n=20\nthe supply-demand gap through energy conservation and efficiency offers the=\n=20\nbest chance of avoiding blackouts this summer.  This can be accomplished mo=\nst=20\neffectively and quickly in two ways:\n\nBuy-down demand\nCalifornia is tapping into an enormous amount of money from the General Fun=\nd=20\nto finance DWR=01,s power purchases.  California could likely reduce demand=\n more=20\neconomically by running an auction to determine the payments businesses wou=\nld=20\nbe willing to receive to reduce their demand for a sustained period (e.g.,=\n=20\nthrough the summer months).  DWR could easily run an on-line auction to=20\ndetermine the price it could pay for these demand reductions.  To=20\nparticipate, businesses would be required to have the metering equipment=20\nnecessary to monitor and verify that they are actually achieving the=20\nreductions.  Enron has developed an on-line auction software package, =01&D=\neal=20\nBench,=018 that it would be willing to contribute to the effort.\n\nUse Price Signals to Incent Voluntary Curtailment\nTo be successful, customers need access to the following key elements:\n\nAn internet based hour-ahead price posting system to track the market price=\n=20\nfor hour-ahead power in real time.=20\nReal-time metering systems for baseline demand and voluntarily curtailment=\n=20\nverification.\nSettlement process that allows for market clearing prices of energy to be=\n=20\npaid for load reduction (=01&Negawatts=018).\n\nThe potential benefits of an effective demand response program would includ=\ne:\n\n=01&creation=018 of additional summer peaking capacity in California, parti=\ncularly=20\nin the short term, without requiring construction of additional generation=\n=20\nresources.\nreduction of  peak or super-peak load on the over-stressed California=20\nelectric system, thus potentially reducing the overall cost of electricity =\nin=20\nthe state.\nfostering of demand elasticity without subjecting customers to the full ris=\nk=20\nof hourly market price volatility by passing market price signals to=20\ncustomers and allowing them to voluntarily shed load and be compensated for=\n=20\nresponding.=20\n\nWe estimate that we could generate a summer 2001 on-peak demand response in=\n=20\nexcess of 400 MW during certain high cost hours, and a demand response for=\n=20\nsummer 2002 on-peak hours that could exceed 1000 MW.  We further estimate=\n=20\nthat the market response to this program from all ESPs could be 2 to 3 time=\ns=20\nthat amount.  We recommend that the State of California provide rebates=20\ndirectly to customers to fund the installation of advanced metering and=20\ncontrol systems that would support load curtailment implementation.\n\nEstablish a truly competitive retail electricity market=01*Legislative vehi=\ncle:=20\nSB27X\nThe only customers who were protected from price volatility in San Diego we=\nre=20\ncustomers who chose Direct Access and signed fixed price deals with energy=\n=20\nservice providers.  Ironically, AB1X takes that important option away from=\n=20\ncustomers and businesses.  It is critical that AB1X be amended to remove th=\ne=20\nprohibition against Direct Access.\n\nEnron\'s legislative proposal would give customers freedom to enter into a=\n=20\ndirect access transaction, while simultaneously addressing the Department o=\nf=20\nWater Resources\' concerns about stranded power costs that might result from=\n=20\ncustomer migration. =20\n\nIn addition, California will only achieve a competitive retail market when=\n=20\nthe utility is removed completely from the procurement function.  Procureme=\nnt=20\nis not a utility core competency, as evidenced by the dire financial=20\ncondition in which the utilities now find themselves.  California should=20\ntherefore begin immediately to phase the utility out of the procurement=20\nfunction entirely, with the goal of having all customers served by a=20\nnon-utility provider within 36 months.  To execute the transition, Californ=\nia=20\nshould hold a series of competitive solicitations over the 36-month period =\nin=20\nwhich competing service providers would bid for the right to serve segments=\n=20\nof utility load.\n\nReturn California=01,s Investor-owned utilities to solvency=01*Legislative =\nvehicle:=20\nAB18X\nUtility bankruptcy will not increase supply and it will not decrease demand=\n. =20\nIn short, bankruptcy does nothing to solve California=01,s supply-demand=20\nimbalance.  In addition, bankruptcy increases the likelihood that consumers=\n=20\nand businesses will bear the significant financial risks of having Californ=\nia=20\nState government assume the role of =01&electricity buyer=018 for an extend=\ned=20\nperiod of time.  Finally, bankruptcy will undermine both investor confidenc=\ne=20\nin California\'s energy markets and the private sector\'s willingness to=20\nparticipate in that market.\n\nCalifornia can return the utilities to financial solvency by implementing a=\n=20\nseries of staged rate increases.  California should design those rate=20\nincreases with the dual goal of returning the utilities to solvency without=\n=20\n=01&shocking=018 the economy or household budgets For example, California c=\nould=20\namortize the recovery of the utilities=01, past debt over a 5-10 year perio=\nd. =20\nIn addition, the magnitude of the rate increase can be reduced in two ways:=\n=20\nFirst, the utilities could absorb some portion of their existing debt in=20\nrecognition of the risk they accepted when they agreed to the structure of =\nAB=20\n1890.  Second, California can =01&net=018 the revenues the utilities have r=\neceived=20\nfrom selling electricity into the Power Exchange against the debts they hav=\ne=20\naccrued due to the retail price cap.\n\n \n\n', 1], ['Appointments Week of August 28, 2000', 'text/plain', 'I seem to have three appointments next week:\n\nTuesday, August 29:  Doctor appointment at 9:40 a.m. (enlightenment)\n\nWednesday, August 30:  Hair appointment @ 2:00 p.m (beauty)\n\nThursday, August 31:  Dental appointment @ 2:00 p.m. (ouch)\n\n\nI plan to return to the office each day, but the dental appointment may take \nawhile.\n\nRosie\n\n', 1], ['Itinerary', 'text/plain', "Eric, sorry for the delay. Instead \nof arriving in Telluride, Co at 12pm on 12/9 we arrived at 10pm, a full ten \nhours later.  This delay caused the waste of one full day of \nvacation. Slate II, president and chief executive offic=\ner=20\nof the Association.=20\nIn addition, four current board members were elected to serve on the=20\nExecutive Committee of the Board of Directors. Georgine, Chairman, President and=\n=20\nCEO, The Union Labor Life Insurance Company (ULLICO); Gilberto Giusti, Esq.=\n,=20\nPinheiro Neto-Advogados; Olivia F. Kirtley, CPA, Vice President, Vermont=20\nAmerican Corporation; Angel Mu=0Foz-Noya, Esq., Lespier & Mu=0Foz-Noya; Dr.=\n Joan=20\nParker, labor-management and employment arbitrator; Dr. Alejandro Ponieman,=\n=20\nAsociacion Interamericana de Mediacion Centro Para la Resolucion de=20\nConflictos; Dennis Rivera, President, 1199 SEIU New York's Health & Human=\n=20\nService Union, AFL-CIO; Juan Rodriguez, Legal Advisor, BP Amoco p.l.c.;=20\nProfessor Theodore J. St. Antoine, James E. and Sarah A. Degan Professor=20\nEmeritus of Law, University of Michigan Law School; and Timothy J. Sullivan=\n,=20\nPresident, the College of William and Mary.=20\nThe leader in conflict management since 1926, the American Arbitration=20\nAssociation is a not-for-profit, public service organization dedicated to t=\nhe=20\nresolution of disputes through the use of arbitration, mediation,=20\nconciliation, negotiation, democratic elections, and other voluntary=20\nprocedures. In 1999, more than 140,000 cases were filed with the American=\n=20\nArbitration Association in a full range of matters including commercial=20\nfinance, construction, labor and employment, environmental, health care,=20\ninsurance, real estate and securities disputes. Through 37 offices in the=\n=20\nUnited States and cooperative agreements with arbitral institutions in 38=\n=20\nother countries, the AAA provides a forum for the hearing of disputes, rule=\ns=20\nand procedures and a roster of impartial experts to hear and resolve cases.\n\n", 1], ['Re: Hi there', 'text/plain', "Hi Debbie:\n\nThanks for your note - it's always nice to hear from MC friends!  \n\nI'm living in Houston and working in the legal department of a large energy \ncompany (Enron). Th=\nis=20\nlist is designed to comply with legal requirements, to deal with potential=\n=20\nconflicts of interest that might result because of our diverse activities,=\n=20\nand to prevent the appearance of impropriety in connection with Enron=01,s=\n=20\ncredit derivatives trading activities.  The credit derivatives Restricted=\n=20\nList is designed for other purposes as well.  For example, a company may be=\n=20\nplaced on the Restricted List if Enron is not able to assume any further=20\ncredit exposure to that company or believes that market conditions do not=\n=20\nwarrant the trading of Credit Derivatives on such Reference Entity.\n\nA company ordinarily will be placed on the credit derivatives Restricted=20\nList, either before or after it has become a Reference Entity on which cred=\nit=20\nderivatives are traded, in the following circumstances:\n\nwhen Enron is actively engaged in effecting a material transaction with=20\nrespect to such company that has not been publicly announced;\n\nwhen Enron has an applicable standstill agreement or other confidentiality=\n=20\nagreement in place with such company;\n\nwhen Enron has a legal duty to keep such company's information confidential=\n=20\nand such company has not expressly consented to being a Reference Entity fo=\nr=20\npurposes of the trading of credit derivatives (such a legal duty may be a=\n=20\nfiduciary duty but may not rise to that level);\n\nwhen some part of Enron acquires material, nonpublic information about a=20\ncompany or its securities in the course of its business activities;\n\nwhen Enron has reached or exceeded its credit limits with respect to such=\n=20\ncompany.\n\nThe purpose of this memorandum is to alert you to this new business and to=\n=20\nrequest your assistance in evaluating proposed Reference Entities prior to=\n=20\nthe trading of credit derivatives based on such companies. General Counsel effective March 1, 2001.\n\n', 1], ['Broker Electronic Transaction Agrmt.', 'text/plain', 'Here is the BETA with our initial comments.\n\n\n', 1], ['Independent Amounts', 'text/plain', 'I\'ve gone back through the ISDA Credit Support Annex and the "green book" and \nmy conclusion is that unless we modify the standard form, we have to give an \nIndependent Amount back to the counterparty when we go out of the money far \nenough (note that the definition of Exposure results in a negative number \nwhen we are out of the money reducing the Credit Support Amount below the \nIndependent Amount).  The theory there is that as the market moves against \nus, we are cushioned by our "out-of-the-moneyness" and will be able to ask \nfor support as the market moves back in our favor before we are actually in \nthe money.  I\'m afraid that Credit has been operating under the assumption \nthat we get to keep Independent Amounts until the Transaction terminates.  We \nneed to set up a system with Credit so we all know what is meant on the \ncredit work sheets -- i.e. whether a cushion or up-front amount should be \ngiven back to the counterparty as we go out of the money or not (maybe the \nparalegals can suggest something?).  I suggest we add the following language \n(taken from the green book) when we are using Paragraph 13 and Credit tells \nus they don\'t want to have to give the cushion amount back, no matter how far \nwe go out of the money:\n\n "Credit Support Amount" will mean the higher of (i) the amount calculated as \nprovided in the definition of that\n  term in Paragraph 3(b) and (ii) the sum of the Pledgor\'s Independent \nAmounts.\n\nI will modify the Force Energy document to include it and, unless you would \nlike to suggest alternative language, ask Tana to add it to our list of \nalternatives for Paragraph 13.\n\n', 1], ['Saturday', 'text/plain', 'Hi Marc!\n\nYes, we\'re having a few friends over Sat. night for "Holiday Cheer" which at \nour house means cocktails by the Christmas tree and maybe some of my \nwonderful-tasting but horrible-for-you egg nog. My impression \nis that the commercial team in Portland is anxious to begin trading \nfinancially.  If this is correct, it would be possible, at least from a legal \npoint of view, to begin trading now under the existing documents.  In each \ncase where a master agreement is already in place, trades entered into before \nthe amendments we want will certainly be binding on both parties.  Our only \nissues with trading under these agreements are where we need more restrictive \ncredit provisions and that resumption of trading before an amendment is \nsigned reduces to some extent our negotiating leverage.  As to the credit \nissue, only the credit group can decide whether or not to permit trading \nunder the existing terms.  As for the negotiating leverage, if the commercial \npeople want to resume trading immediately, my suggestion would be to let them \ngo ahead. I'm getting questions from the EOL \nteam in Houston as to our time estimate to completion and wondered if you had \nheard back from outside counsel.\n\n", 1], ['Pets in the Office', 'text/plain', 'Pets In the Office\n It\'s A Growing Trend\n\n In the dog-eat-dog world of business, there\'s a growing trend at some \ncompanies. Workers are bringing their\n pets to the office. \n\n Chip Paucek, who produces educational videos and television programs, has \nbeen taking his golden retriever,\n Hoss, to work for the last five years. Paucek and Hoss visited The Early \nShow and talked with Co-Anchor\n Jane Clayson. \n\n The dog has became the office mascot, says Paucek. "He brings a lot of \nemotion and people love it. He\'s\n very relaxed." \n\n But Paucek, as co-president of his company, has the freedom to bring Hoss to \nthe office if he wishes. Not\n everybody can bring their pet to work. \n\n "A lot of it depends on the dog," says Paucek, who explains that Hoss is not \na rowdy dog. \n\n "He just hangs out," explains Paucek. "He\'s easy to get along with." \n\n Hoss has free rein at the office. When Paucek is away on trips, "My wife \nbrings him in and drops him off at\n the office," Paucek says. \n\n While there are plenty of positives to pets in the workplace, there are also \nmany legal issues to consider. John\n Challenger, CEO of an international placement company, agrees that the trend \nof bringing pets to the work\n place is really growing. \n\n "More and more companies in this tight labor market are trying to make their \nworking place\n employee-friendly and many are looking at bringing pets into the workplace," \nsays Challenger \n\n He points out, however, that there are serious issues that employers and \nemployees need to explore before\n they adopt a pets-in-the-office policy. \n\n "One of the things that the companies must do, before they jump into a \npolicy like that, is take a poll\n of their employees and find out what they\'re thinking. If you have certain \nemployees that don\'t feel\n comfortable with pets, you might want to rethink the policy." \n\n There are liability questions as well. For example, the company might be \nliable if a dog or cat bites or\n scratches another employee. \n\n "The company ought to talk with their attorneys before they put this kind of \npolicy in effect," says\n Challenger. "The employee needs to understand that if their dog bites \nsomeone or the cat scratches\n someone, it can\'t be the company\'s fault." \n\n Allergies are a major deterrent to bringing cats to the office. \n\n "Many people are allergic to cat hair. You have to think, as an employer, \nwill you put them in a\n certain part of your space. What about people who are afraid of animals? \nMany don\'t feel\n comfortable with them around. Just how many do you want? Do you want cats \nand dogs and what\n about birds? What about the noise of birds?" \n\n Paucek admits that when there\'s more than one pet in the office, "It gets \nchaotic." \n\n In 1997, the American Animal Hospital Association surveyed 1,225 pet owners. \nThey found that: \n\n      21% of those surveyed had taken their pets to work \n      76% feel guilty about leaving their pets at home while they\'re on the \njob \n      33% said they leave a TV or radio on for their animals\n\n\n If a company decides to allow pets in the office, they should: \n\n      poll employees before they let the pets come \n      provide a written policy about pets and list which pets are not welcome \nin the office \n      establish an off-limits-to-pets area \n      make sure employees bring documents proving pets are vaccinated \n      bar noisy, destructive, or messy animals from the office \n      tell employees to keep control of their animals at all times\n\n\n If many employees want to bring their pets to the office, the company should \nmake a rotating schedule. \n\n When the pets-in-the-office policy does work, it\'s great. VERY \ngood news!\n\n', 1], ['FYI', 'text/plain', "Western Power Market Stands 'Poised on the \nPrecipice' According to the ICF Kaiser Consulting\nGroup's 1999 Bulk Power Outlook\n\nFAIRFAX, Va., June 1 /PRNewswire/ -- Power markets in the Western System \nCoordinating Council are ``poised on the\nprecipice'' of capacity shortfalls and extreme price volatility this summer \nand next, according to a new study of the regional\nmarket by the Energy Practice of the ICF Kaiser Consulting Group. ``The West \nstands at least a one in three chance of\nexperiencing price spikes similar to those seen in the Midwest market during \nthe summer of 1998,'' said Judah Rose, a Senior\nVice President with the Group and the director of the ICF study.\n\nICF's analysis of the West points to a number of key near-term implications: \n\n     Regional Capacity Deficits. The region is in a delicate supply/demand \nbalance, with most sub-regions of the West relying\n     on a capacity surplus in the Pacific Northwest to meet near-term peak \ncapacity requirements. Because demand growth is\n     outpacing new supply additions, those deficits will only become more \nextreme over the next two years.\n     Volatility Exacerbated by Hydroelectric Dependence. A fifth consecutive \nyear of above-average hydroelectric generation\n     -- the principle cause of the Pacific Northwest surplus -- will again \nmask the West's precarious supply/demand balance in\n     1999. However, if the drought conditions of the early 1990s resurface, \nthe West will find itself at an even greater risk of\n     price spikes.\n     Upward Pressure on Prices. Prices are on an upward trend for 1999 and \n2000, the result of both higher regional spot\n     natural gas prices and the increasing value of ``pure capacity'' -- the \nvalue of ensuring reliability for consumers. \n\nThe study also evaluates the long-term future of the Western market and \nhighlights the following key results: \n\n     Capacity Requirements Growing Steadily. The region's underlying demand \ngrowth is strong, creating a long-term regional\n     capacity need totaling more than 18,000 MW by 2005, unless there is a \nserious economic downturn in the region.\n     Energy Prices Trending Downward. The trend for long-term energy prices \nis for negative real growth through 2010, but\n     the region will remain susceptible to near-term volatility while market \ninstitutions continue to evolve and new supply is\n     slowly added over the next few years.\n     Capacity Prices Rising Slowly. Current low capacity values will continue \nto rise (but still remain below many other\n     regions) as new, more efficient generation is added.\n     Strong Gas Demand Growth at Stable Prices. Gas demand for power \ngeneration is poised to more than double by 2010,\n     with the most explosive growth in the Rocky Mountain and Southwest \nsubregions. Even so, the West region's vast gas\n     supply potential appears capable of meeting this growth with little, if \nany, real price appreciation through 2010. \n\n``The Western U.S. Region volume of our Bulk Power Outlook, along with the \nother five regional volumes, offers\ncomprehensive insights into the rapidly changing North American power \nmarkets,'' said Sudhakar Kesavan, President of the\nICF Kaiser Consulting Group. ``No other firm can match our analytic \ncapabilities -- which are based on an understanding of the\nfundamentals driving electric power markets -- and the knowledge gained from \nworking one- on-one with the market's key\nplayers.''\n\nAbout the ICF 1999 Bulk Power Outlook\n\nICF's analysis of the Western market is part of the 1999 Bulk Power Outlook, \nan authoritative assessment of North American\nregional bulk power markets through 2010. The study also provides the \nanalytical basis for ICF's extensive and well-respected\nconsulting services providing market assessment, asset valuation, and project \ndue diligence evaluations for the North American\nelectric power and natural gas industries. The 1999 Bulk Power Outlook is \navailable for six regional markets -- West,\nNortheast, Midwest, Southeast, South Central, and Canada -- well as a \nNational Subscription, which includes the six regional\nstudies and a North American summary volume. Additional information on the \n1999 Bulk Power Outlook, including a\nprospectus, sample volume, and order form, can be found at \nhttp://www.icfkaiser.com/consulting/products/BPS.htm.\n\nThe 1999 Bulk Power Outlook is part of the ICF Kaiser Consulting Group's \ngrowing family of products and services. Related\nstudies on energy and environmental issues recently completed by ICF include \nthe SO2 Allowance Market Outlook and the\nOzone Transport Region: NOx Allowance Study, which detail ICF's views on air \nemissions allowance markets.\n\nFor information about the 1999 Bulk Power Outlook and related studies, or any \nof ICF Consulting Group's products and\nservices, call Aldyn Hoekstra at 415/507-7188 or Cheryl Aronson at \n415/507-7151. Additional information the ICF Kaiser\nConsulting Group can be found on ICF's Web site at \nhttp://www.icfkaiser.com/consulting.\n\nAbout the Company\n\nHeadquartered in Fairfax, Virginia, ICF Kaiser is one of the United States' \nlargest engineering, construction, program\nmanagement, and consulting services companies. Its more than 4,000 employees, \nlocated in 60 offices around the world,\nprovide fully integrated capabilities to clients in four related market \nareas: environment, infrastructure, industry, and energy. ICF\nKaiser reported gross revenue of more than $1.2 billion for the 12 months \nended December 31, 1998. All references to ICF\nKaiser indicate ICF Kaiser International, Inc. and any of its subsidiaries.\n\nForward-Looking Statements and Certain Factors Affecting ICF Kaiser and Its \nBusinesses\n\nThis release contains ``forward-looking statements'' within the meaning of \nthe Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995,\nwhich are identified by the use of forward-looking terminology such as \n``may,'' ``will,'' ``could,'' ``should,'' ``expect,'' ``believe,''\n``anticipate,'' ``aim,'' ``intend,'' ``plan,'' ``estimate,'' or ``continue'' \nor the negative thereof or other variations thereof. Hosiery was meticulously suspended from the forward edge of the \nwood burning caloric apparatus, pursuant to our anticipatory pleasure \nregarding an imminent visitation from an eccentric philanthropist among whose \nfolkloric appellations is the honorific title of St. Nicholas (party of the \nsecond part).\n\nThe prepubescent siblings, comfortably ensconced in their respective \naccommodations of repose, were experiencing subconscious visual \nhallucinations of variegated fruit confections moving rhythmically through \ntheir cerebrums.  My conjugal partner and I, attired in our nocturnal head \ncoverings, were about to take slumberous advantage of the hibernal darkness \nwhen upon the avenaceous exterior portion of the grounds there ascended such \na cacophony of dissonance that I felt compelled to arise with alacrity from \nmy place of repose for the purpose of ascertaining the precise source thereof.\n\nHastening to the casement, I forthwith opened the barriers sealing this \nfenestration, noting thereupon that the lunar brilliance without, reflected \nas it was on the surface of a recent crystalline precipitation,  might be \nsaid to rival that of the solar meridian itself - thus permitting my \nincredulous optical sensory organs to behold a miniature airborne runnered \nconveyance drawn by eight diminutive specimens of the genus Rangifer,  \npiloted by a minuscule, aged chauffeur so ebullient and nimble  that it \nbecame instantly apparent to me that he was indeed our  anticipated caller. \nWith his ungulate motive power traveling at what may possibly have been more \nvertiginous velocity than patriotic alar predators,  he vociferated loudly, \nexpelled breath musically through contracted  labia,  and addressed each of \nthe octet by his or her respective cognomen -  "Now Dasher, now Dancer..." et \nal. - guiding them to the uppermost exterior level of our abode, through \nwhich structure I could readily distinguish the concatenations of each of the \n32 cloven pedal extremities.\n\nAs I retracted my cranium from its erstwhile location, and was performing a \n180-degree pivot, our distinguished visitant achieved - with utmost celerity \nand via a downward leap - entry by way of the smoke passage. He was clad \nentirely in animal pelts soiled by the ebony residue from oxidations of \ncarboniferous fuels which had accumulated on the walls thereof. His \nresemblance to a street vendor I attributed largely to the plethora of \nassorted playthings which he bore dorsally in a commodious cloth receptacle.\n\nHis orbs were scintillant with reflected luminosity, while his submaxillary \ndermal indentations gave every evidence of engaging amiability. The \ncapillaries of his malar regions and nasal appurtenance were engorged with \nblood which suffused the subcutaneous layers, the former approximating the \ncoloration of Albion\'s floral emblem,  the latter that of the Prunus avium, \nor sweet cherry. His amusing sub- and supralabials resembled nothing so much \nas a common loop knot, and their ambient hirsute facial adornment appeared \nlike small, tabular and columnar crystals of frozen water.\n\nClenched firmly between his incisors was a smoking piece whose grey fumes, \nforming a tenuous ellipse about his occiput, were suggestive of a decorative \nseasonal circlet of holly.  His visage was wider than it was high, and when \nhe waxed audibly mirthful, his corpulent abdominal region undulated in the \nmanner of impectinated fruit syrup in a hemispherical container. He was, in \nshort, neither more nor less than an obese, jocund, multigenarian gnome, the \noptical perception of whom rendered me visibly frolicsome despite every \neffort to refrain from so being. By rapidly lowering and then elevating one \neyelid and rotating his head slightly to one side, he indicated that \ntrepidation on my part was groundless. Without utterance and with dispatch, \nhe commenced filling the aforementioned appended hosiery with various of the \naforementioned articles of merchandise extracted from his aforementioned \npreviously dorsally transported cloth receptacle. Upon completion of this \ntask, he executed an abrupt about-face, placed a single manual digit in \nlateral juxtaposition to his olfactory organ, inclined his cranium forward in \na gesture of leave-taking, and forthwith effected his egress by renegotiating \n(in reverse) the smoke passage. He then propelled himself in a short vector \nonto his conveyance, directed a musical expulsion of air through his \ncontracted oral sphincter to the antlered quadrupeds of burden, and proceeded \nto soar aloft in a movement  hitherto observable chiefly among the \nseed-bearing portions of a common weed. But I overheard his parting \nexclamation, audible immediately prior to his vehiculation beyond the limits \nof visibility:\n\n"Ecstatic Yuletide to the planetary constituency,\nand to that self same assemblage,\nmy sincerest wishes for a salubriously beneficial and gratifyingly \npleasurable period between sunset and dawn."\n\n', 1], ['No More Confirms Agreement', 'text/plain', 'Here is a first draft of an amendment agreement. Assuming the meeting stays scheduled, I will schedule an \ninternal meeting to briefly go over the EEI Into definition before we meet \nwith Dynegy.\n\nAs you are aware, in connection with the EEI effort we worked extensively \nwith a large group of industry participants to define  what an Into Product \nis.  Dynegy and PECO were the two companies that were very outspoken against \nthey way the product ultimately got defined.  Dynegy put on a big dog and \npony show before a large group of industry participants trying to argue that \nEEI\'s Into product was flawed.   Their position, while not completely \nexpressed, hinges on the concept that if you sell an Into Product and are \nmaking deliveries on firm transmission, then the Seller will always be \nexcused from performance if the firm transmission gets cut for any reason (in \ngeneral, this is contrary to EEI which obligates the Seller to go to another \ninterface unless the cut was due to Buyer\'s use of non firm transmission when \nfirm was available or due to Buyer\'s attempt to move the energy away from the \nreceiving control area).  Dynegy\'s approach was driven by the fact that they \nhave extensive generation and that the vast majority of their deals go \nphysical.  At the time, we suggested that if they were worried about cuts in \nfirm transmission, then they needed to sell a transmission contingent \nproduct.  Dynegy\'s concept was rejected at the EEI meetings.\n\nI hope that the meeting will accomplish the following goals:\n\n1.  Get Dynegy to agree to trade Into with us under a common Into definition \n- Dynegy will not sign an EEI with us because of the Into definition.  We \ntrade Into extensively with them, but clearly do not have a common \nunderstanding of what we are trading.  Critical to clear up this ambiguity.\n\n2. Secure Dynegy as an advocate of EEI - Because Dynegy was so vocal against \nEEI\'s Into definition, if they now started using EEI, it would further boost \nacceptance of the contract and isolate PECO as the only other major voice \nagainst the Into definition.\n\n3. Reexamine the Into Product as it is currently drafted and consider what \nwill happen as access to transmission changes - Because the Into product is \nsuch an important part of East trading today, it is critical that internally \nwe all agree how it should operate. Additionally, it is critical that we \nstart thinking about how the Into product will be affected by changes in \ntransmission, such as the advent of RTOs (with long term Into deals we may \nwant to consider addressing what happens if the receiving control area goes \ninto an RTO)\n\nCall me with any questions/thoughts.\n\nThanks\nElizabeth\n 36349\n\n', 1], ["A Midwesterner's view", 'text/plain', 'Chi is now confused. The crow answered: "Sure, why not." So, the\n >  rabbit sat on the ground below the crow, and rested. All of a sudden,\n >  a fox appeared, jumped on the rabbit and ate it.\n >\n >  Management Lesson: To be sitting and doing nothing,\n >  you must be sitting very, very high up.\n >\n >  Lesson Number Two\n >  *****************\n >   A turkey was chatting with a bull.\n >\n >  "I would love to be able to get to the top of that\n >  tree," sighed the turkey, "but I haven\'t got the energy.\n >\n >  "Well, why don\'t you nibble on some of my\n >  droppings?" replied the bull. "They\'re packed with nutrients."\n >\n >  The turkey pecked at a lump of dung and found that\n >  it actually gave him enough strength to reach the first\n >  branch of the tree.\n >\n >  The next day, after eating some more dung, he\n >  reached the second branch.\n >  Finally after a fortnight, there he was proudly\n >  perched at the top of the tree. Soon he was promptly spotted by a farmer,\n > who\n >  shot the turkey out of the tree.\n >\n >  Management Lesson: Bullshit might get you to the\n >  top, but it won\'t keep you there.\n >\n >  Lesson Number Three\n >  *******************\n >   When the body was first made, all the parts wanted\n >  to be Boss.\n > The brain said, "I should be Boss because I control the whole body\'s\n >  responses and functions."\n >\n >  The feet said, "We should be Boss as we carry the brain about  and\n >  get him to where he wants to go."\n >\n >  The hands said, "We should be the  Boss because we do all the work\n >  and earn all the money."\n >\n >  And so it went on and on with the heart, the lungs\n >  and the eyes until finally the asshole spoke up. All the parts laughed\n >  at the idea of the asshole being the Boss. So the asshole went on\n >  strike, blocked itself up and refused to work. Within a short time the\n > eyes\n >  became crossed, the hands clenched, the feet twitched, the heart and\n >  lungs began to panic and the brain fevered. Eventually they all decided\n > that\n >  the asshole should be the Boss, so the motion was passed. All the other\n >  parts did all the work while the Boss just sat and passed out the shit!\n >\n >  Management Lesson: You don\'t need brains to be a\n >  Boss - any asshole will do.\n >\n >  Lesson Number Four\n >  ******************\n >   A little bird was flying south for the winter. It\n >  was so cold, the bird froze and fell to the ground in a large field.\n > While\n >  it was lying there, a cow came by and dropped some dung on it. As the\n >  frozen bird lay there in the pile of cow dung, it began to realize how\n > warm\n >  it was. The dung was actually thawing him out! He lay there all warm and\n >  happy and soon began to sing for joy. A passing cat heard the bird\n >  singing and came to investigate. Following the sound, the cat discovered\n >  the bird under the pile of cow dung and promptly dug him out and ate\n >  him!\n >\n >                          Management Lessons:\n >\n >           1) Not everyone who drops shit on you is\n >  your enemy.\n >           2) Not everyone who gets you out of shit is\n >  your friend.\n >           3) And when you\'re in deep shit, keep your\n >  mouth shut! >>\n\n', 1], ['November PL by Trader', 'text/plain', 'Vlady,\n\nHere is the P&L breakout you requested. Traders put the two together, anticipated a \nsupply crunch and drove gas prices to record heights. \n\n"Traders do that all the time; they\'re looking forward," said William Burson, \na trader. "It makes the market for natural gas." \n\nBut the market\'s response perplexed Chris McGill, the American Gas \nAssociation\'s director of gas supply and transportation. He had compiled the \nstorage numbers since they were first published in 1994, and in his view the \nnumbers were being misinterpreted to show a situation far bleaker than \nreality. \n\n"It\'s a little frustrating that they don\'t take the time to understand what \nwe are reporting," McGill said. \n\nAs consumer outrage builds over high heating bills, the hunt for reasons -- \nand culprits -- is on. Some within the natural gas industry are pointing \nfingers at Wall Street. \n\nStephen Adik, senior vice president of the Indiana utility NiSource, recently \nstepped before an industry conference and blamed the market\'s speculators for \nthe rise in gas prices. \n\n"It\'s my firm belief ... that today\'s gas prices are being manipulated," Adik \ntold the trade magazine Public Utilities Fortnightly. \n\nIn California, where natural gas spikes have contributed to an electric \nutility crisis, six investigations are looking into the power industry. \n\nCloser to home, observers note that utilities and regulators share the blame \nfor this winter\'s startling gas bills, having failed to protect their \ncustomers and constituents from such price spikes. \n\nMost utilities, often with the acquiescence of regulators, failed to take \nprecautions such as fixed-rate contracts and hedging -- a sort of price \ninsurance -- that could have protected their customers by locking in gas \nprices before they soared. \n\n"We\'re passing on our gas costs, which we have no control over," said Paul \nSnider, a spokesman for Missouri Gas Energy. \n\nBut critics say the utilities shirked their responsibility to customers. \n\n"There\'s been a failure of risk management by utilities, and that needs to \nchange," said Ed Krapels, director of gas power services for Energy Security \nAnalysis Inc., an energy consulting firm in Wakefield, Mass. \n\n\nHot topic \n\nConsumers know one thing for certain: Their heating bills are up sharply. In \nmany circles, little else is discussed. \n\nThe Rev. Vincent Fraser of Glad Tidings Assembly of God in Kansas City is \nfacing a $1,456 December bill for heating the church -- more than double the \nprevious December\'s bill. Church members are suffering from higher bills as \nwell. \n\nThe Sunday collection is down, said Fraser, who might have to forgo part of \nhis salary. For the first time, the church is unable to meet its financial \npledge to overseas missionaries because the money is going to heating. \n\n"It\'s the talk of the town here," he said. \n\nA year ago that wasn\'t a fear. Wholesale gas prices hovered just above $2 per \nthousand cubic feet -- a level that producers say didn\'t make it worthwhile \nto drill for gas. Utilities were even cutting the gas prices paid by \ncustomers. \n\nBut trouble was brewing. By spring, gas prices were hitting $4 per thousand \ncubic feet, just as utilities were beginning to buy gas to put into storage \nfor winter. \n\nThere was a dip in the fall, but then prices rebounded. By early November, \nprices were at $5 per thousand cubic feet. The federal Energy Information \nAdministration was predicting sufficient but tight gas supplies and heating \nbills that would be 30 percent to 40 percent higher. \n\nBut $10 gas was coming. Below-normal temperatures hit much of the country, \nincluding the Kansas City area, and fears about tight supplies roiled the gas \nmarkets. \n\n"It\'s all about the weather," said Krapels of Energy Security Analysis. \n\nWholesale prices exploded to $10 per thousand cubic feet, led by the New York \ntraders. Natural gas sealed its reputation as the most price-volatile \ncommodity in the world. \n\n\nSetting the price \n\nIn the 1980s, the federal government took the caps off the wellhead price of \ngas, allowing it to float. In 1990, the New York Mercantile began trading \ncontracts for future delivery of natural gas, and that market soon had \nwidespread influence over gas prices. \n\nThe futures contracts are bought and sold for delivery of natural gas as soon \nas next month or as far ahead as three years. Suppliers can lock in sale \nprices for the gas they expect to produce. And big gas consumers, from \nutilities to companies such as Farmland Industries Inc., can lock in what \nthey pay for the gas they expect to use. \n\nThere are also speculators who trade the futures contracts with no intention \nof actually buying or selling the gas -- and often with little real knowledge \nof natural gas. \n\nBut if they get on the right side of a price trend, traders don\'t need to \nknow much about gas -- or whatever commodity they\'re trading. Like all \nfutures, the gas contracts are purchased on credit. That leverage adds to \ntheir volatility and to the traders\' ability to make or lose a lot of money \nin a short time. \n\nAs December began, the price of natural gas on the futures market was less \nthan $7 per thousand cubic feet. By the end of the month it was nearly $10. \nMuch of the spark for the rally came from the American Gas Association\'s \nweekly storage numbers. \n\nUtilities buy ahead and store as much as 50 percent of the gas they expect to \nneed in the winter. \n\nGoing into the winter, the storage levels were about 5 percent less than \naverage, in part because some utilities were holding off on purchasing, in \nhopes that the summer\'s unusually high $4 to $5 prices would drop. \n\nStill, the American Gas Association offered assurances that supplies would be \nsufficient. But when below-normal temperatures arrived in November, the \nconcerns increased among traders that supplies could be insufficient. \n\nThen the American Gas Association reported the lowest year-end storage \nnumbers since they were first published in 1994. Still, said the \nassociation\'s McGill, there was sufficient gas in storage. \n\nBut some utility executives didn\'t share that view. William Eliason, vice \npresident of Kansas Gas Service, said that if December\'s cold snap had \ncontinued into January, there could have been a real problem meeting demand. \n\n"I was getting worried," he said. \n\nThen suddenly the market turned when January\'s weather turned warmer. \nWednesday\'s storage numbers were better than expected, and futures prices \ndropped more than $1 per thousand cubic feet. \n\n\nJust passing through \n\nSome utilities said there was little else to do about the price increase but \npass their fuel costs on to customers. \n\nAmong area utilities, Kansas Gas Service increased its customers\' cost-of-gas \ncharge earlier this month to $8.68 per thousand cubic feet. And Missouri Gas \nEnergy has requested an increase to $9.81, to begin Wednesday. \n\nSheila Lumpe, chairwoman of the Missouri Public Service Commission, said last \nmonth that because utilities passed along their wholesale costs, little could \nbe done besides urging consumers to join a level-payment plan and to conserve \nenergy. \n\nKansas Gas Service had a small hedging program in place, which is expected to \nsave an average customer about $25 this winter. \n\nMissouri Gas Energy has no hedging program. It waited until fall to seek an \nextension of the program and then decided to pass when regulators would not \nguarantee that it could recover its hedging costs. \n\nNow utilities are being asked to justify the decisions that have left \ncustomers with such high gas bills. And regulators are being asked whether \nthey should abandon the practice of letting utilities pass along their fuel \ncosts. \n\nOn Friday, Doug Micheel, senior counsel of the Missouri Office of the Public \nCounsel, said his office would ask the Missouri Public Service Commission to \nperform an emergency audit of Missouri Gas Energy\'s gas purchasing practices. \n\n"Consumers are taking all the risk," Micheel said. "It\'s time to consider \nsome changes." \n\n\nTo reach Steve Everly, call (816) 234-4455 or send e-mail to \nseverly@kcstar.com. \n\n\n\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n--\nAll content , 2001 The Kansas City Star  \n\n', 1], ['Re: your moms birthday', 'text/plain', 'mac,\n\nWe will be there on the 9th and I will bring the paperwork.\n\nphillip\n\n', 1], ['Re: Please respond', 'text/plain', 'message board\n\n', 1], [None, 'text/plain', 'Dave,\n\nThe back office is having a hard time dealing with the $11 million dollars \nthat is to be recognized as transport expense by the west desk then recouped \nfrom the Office of the Chairman. The respective obligations of the \nparties do not commence until the facilities are "tested and placed in \nservice."  We notified our shippers by telephone yesterday that the \nfacilities were in service.  The compressor has since been taken down because \nof excessive vibration and an unusual whining noise of undetermined origin.  \nEE&CC does not know how long it will take to correct the problems; they do \nnot have enough information yet to even give an estimate.  Based on our \nexperience with Hubbard, it could take months to correct the problem.  Today, \nwe\'ve been able to deliver all nominated gas simply because noms did not \nexceed our existing capacity.  Nominations are expected to exceed existing \ncapacity this week, in which case we will have to allocate.\n\nGiven the uncertainty involved, from a PR standpoint I believe it would be \nbest to tell the customers that because of unforeseen circumstances we are \nnot in service after all, that we apologize for the mistake and will do our \nbest to provide service on a daily or interruptible basis.    When the \ncompressor is actually tested and really in service, we\'ll let them know.  \nThe downside:  we get no reservation charge at all.  (estimated loss:  \n$25,000/month)\nThe upside:  in the long run we probably save face with our customers.\n\nFrom a short-term economic standpoint, the better choice appears to be not to \nrevoke our "in-service" announcement.  When summer weather kicks in, we\'ll \nprobably have to allocate every day.  On our EBB we will have to give some \nreason for the allocation (or if we don\'t, shippers will demand an \nexplanation anyway).  Shippers\' rights to a reservation refund will be \ntriggered.  \nThe downside:  shippers will never trust us again.  Also, we could be subject \nto fraud or related causes of action for representing the compressor was "in \nservice" when we knew it was not.  \nThe upside:  on the off chance no one files a lawsuit and wins, we might at \nleast get to keep some of the reservation charges owed us, to the extent \ndeliveries don\'t fall below 75% of nominated quantities for a period of \nlonger than 75 days in months other than July and August this summer.  (In \nJuly and August, we don\'t get any reservation charge for amounts not \ndelivered).  We just need to keep in mind that normally the pipeline runs \nfull in the summer months, and Gallup capacity was sold with that assumption \nin mind.\n\nHaven\'t had time to do a formal write-up; if you want me to turn this into a \nmemo for wider distribution, let me know. \nhttp://www.intbadfed.org/home.html#anchor443465\n\n", 1], ['TW Options update', 'text/plain', 'Transwestern held its Transport Options Workshop on August 31.   Commercial \nand regulatory representatives of BP-Amoco, Burlington, Conoco, Coral, \nDynegy, Phillips and Reliant attended.  After a brief overview of the \nproposed filing, TW opened the floor for questions and comments.  Here is a \nsummary of the comments.\n\nMarketing affiliate concerns.  BP\'s regulatory representative expressed \nconcern that TW\'s marketing affiliates would be able to use options to game \nthe system.  In BP\'s example, since TW and ENA are both Enron companies, ENA \ncould purchase an "out of the money" call option essentially cost free, since \nits affiliate (TW) would have the ability to buy the option back.  Proceeds \nfrom ENA\'s ability to then "move the market" through the establishment of the \nlong basis position would go directly to Enron\'s bottom line.  BP suggested \nthat TW\'s marketing affiliates be banned from purchasing options, or that the \nmarketing affiliate be required to credit 100% of the option proceeds to \nother shippers.  Although BP admits that Transwestern\'s prior dealings with \nENA have not been suspect, BP fears that TW\'s filing will set a precedent for \nother pipelines to offer a similar service.  Since TW will be the first \npipeline to offer such services, BP wants TW\'s program to be as restricted as \npossible.  Dynegy echoed BP\'s concern regarding possible affiliate abuse, but \nrather than shelve the program entirely, Dynegy reiterated an earlier \nsuggestion that Transwestern be required to credit back the difference \nbetween the option fee paid by an affiliate and the next highest bidder, if \nthe affiliate\'s bid exceeds the next highest by a certain percentage.  \n\nTW\'s response was that while actual abuse of an options program by a \nmarketing affiliate may be a legitimate concern, owing to its unassailable \nrecord in this area, TW should be entitled to a presumption that it has \ncomplied and will continue to comply with Commission policy covering the sale \nof capacity to marketing affiliates, and was not inclined to voluntarily \ninclude any limitations on the options program.  If BP and others have \nserious concerns regarding the Commission\'s overall policy on marketing \naffiliates, those issues should be raised in a separate proceeding that \napplies to all interstate pipelines.\n\nRight of first refusal.  Burlington asked whether options would replace the \nright of first refusal.  TW\'s  response was that ROFR will still be available \npursuant to the terms and conditions of our tariff.\n\nNegotiated rate.  BP\'s representative claimed that option contracts will \nconstitute a negotiated rate and that each deal will need to be filed as \nsuch.  TW did not respond to this or discuss it further.  However, TW\'s \nposition at this point is that since the option fee is part of the \ntransportation rate, transportation deals that include the option amendment \nwill only be considered negotiated rate deals if the total rate including the \noption fee exceeds the maximum transport rate.  \n\nHoarding capacity.  Using the recent large block sale of capacity on El Paso \nas an example, several customers expressed concern that the options program \nwould make it easier for a shipper to hoard capacity.  It was not clear why \nsome of the workshop participants thought that the sale of options would \ncreate more opportunity for hoarding capacity than already exists.  Perhaps \nbecause the option fee is a lesser cost than the transport rate for the \nunderlying capacity, their perception was that options would simply make \nhoarding cheaper and easier.  TW acknowledged that the potential for \nwithholding capacity from the market is one reason for FERC\'s current policy \nagainst reserving capacity for shippers.  Although TW did not commit to \nplacing any limits on the either the quantity of capacity or options for \ncapacity that any one shipper may own, it is possible that FERC may require \nTW to do so in a final order.\n\nOur plan is to meet with PG&E and SoCalGas in California the week of \nSeptember 11 to go over details of the program, and to finalize the FERC \nfiling by mid-September.\n\n\n\n', 1], ['draft of options filing', 'text/plain', "Take a look at the attached and let's talk tomorrow if at all possible. She was also able to la=\ny=20\nself-deprecation aside, however, and in Northanger Abbey she declared that=\n=20\nnovels -- her chosen genre -- are works in which "the greatest powers of th=\ne=20\nmind are displayed, in which the most thorough knowledge of human nature, t=\nhe=20\nhappiest delineation of its varieties, the liveliest effusions of wit and=\n=20\nhumour are conveyed to the world in the best chosen language."=01(\n\nAusten\'s work brims with general statements that are contradicted by the=20\npeople in her stories. Unscheduled maintenance is defined as unanticipated or unplanned \nmaintenance on the pipeline system required to be performed to ensure that \ngas continues to flow in months other than Dec., Jan., Feb., July and Aug.  \n\nAssuming we could even classify the proposed activity as "maintenance," I\'m \nnot sure we could get away with saying it was unanticipated or unplanned, as \nthe Gallup expansion has been in the works for some time.  I am also not \ncompletely comfortable calling this "force majeure" because part of the \ntariff definition is that the event was not within the control of either \nparty; however, since the definition does include "binding order of any court \nor governmental authority," we could possibly say this is force majeure if \nwe\'re reducing the pressure in order to comply with a DOT pipeline safety \nrule.  (In that event, our notice on the EBB would be a force majeure \nnotice.)  If not, we can argue that since this is not "maintenance," but \nsimply being done to construct the expansion in a safe and prudent manner, \nthe shippers\' rights are not triggered under the reservation charge reduction \nprovisions.  In that case, damages (if any) would have to be pursued under \nordinary contract law.  \n\nI realize that this is not a very satisfactory answer; however, the outage is \ngoing to be relatively short, and no shipper in recent memory has availed \nitself of the reservation charge reduction.  I recommend we give shippers \nreasonable notice of the pressure reduction so that they can make alternate \nplans -- this will reduce the likelihood that they will feel revengeful.\n\nPlease call (x30596) or e-mail if you have further questions.\n\n', 1], ['Topock', 'text/plain', 'John Buchanan and I discussed TW\'s transfer of gas from the PG&E/Topock \nreceipt/delivery point to the PG&E/Topock Park N\' Ride point to implement \nTW\'s use of PG&E\'s Market Center service. It seems a simple enough extension of the principle that \ncapacity must be awarded on a nondiscriminatory basis.  However, I did not \nfind any case that stands for that exact proposition.  As you may be aware, \nthe Commission made Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America (NGPL) come up \nwith a way to ensure that it awarded capacity one a nondiscriminatory \nbasis...because NGPL was found to have been giving preferential treatment to \nits shippers.  NGPL\'s solution was to come up with an auction process, and \nthere is a whole line of cases if you\'re interested.  The underlying \npresumption is that if you set up a system under which all capacity is \nawarded and stick with that system, there is no way you could be acting \ndiscriminatorily.  But of course the Commission never comes out and says this \neven though it should be obvious.\n\nProbably the best we can do is extrapolate from 1) the tariff and 2) the NGA \n(doesn\'t it also say we have to provide service on a not unduly discrim. \nbasis?).  Also, in your memo I\'d give an example; i.e., if we notify shippers \nof our auction process and set a deadline for bidding, but then award the \ncapacity to Sempra (assuming Sempra requested capacity after the posting), we \nwill have unduly discriminated against all the other shippers who had to \nparticipate in the auction process.  \n\nMaybe in future postings on Enrononline we should include a statement to the \neffect that the capacity posted will not be awarded except thru the \nEnrononline process.\n\nNow for some trivia.  Remember we were discussing with Shelley whether we \ncould post a different method (other than that prescribed in the tariff) for \ndetermining best bid?  In my Westlaw search I ran across the relevant case.  \nIn Northwest Pipeline, 85 FERC P 61,335, the Commission stated:  "The \nCommission has previously given pipelines the leeway, in open season \nprovisions, to either include in their tariff a single non-discriminatory bid \nevaluation methodology, or provide themselves the flexibility of choosing \ndifferent non-discriminatory bid evaulation methods for different \ntransactions, provided that the pipeline posts the bid evaluation methodology \nbefore the bidding process begins."  The only problem is I am not sure we \nhave that "flexibility" since the tariff does not expressly allow us to post \na different method.  Maybe next time we do a tariff cleanup we could add some \nlanguage allowing us to do so.\n\nI have to move on to my next project but if you want me to comment on what \nyou write I\'d be happy to.\n\n\n', 1], ['Recourse rate dilemma: the sequel', 'text/plain', 'Maria and Drew, this is a long-winded e-mail but please bear with me...\n\nThe problem:\n\nAs you probably remember, several months ago several of us met to discuss the \nfollowing language in the ROFR portion of Transwestern\'s tariff: "if the rate \nbid exceeds the maximum tariff rate, then the rate will be considered to be \nthe maximum tariff rate," and the additional frustrating language "[a]ll \navailable capacity shall be allocated under these procedures . . .."  At our \nlast meeting, we concluded that probably the best way to ensure that TW could \ncapture the true value of the capacity would be to link the negotiated rate \nto index prices.  However, since this usually involves an unacceptable amount \nof risk to both the shipper and TW, the marketers haven\'t done any \nindex-based rates and have no current plans to enter into any such deals.  I \nhave been asked by the Commercial Group to revisit this issue and to think of \nother ways we could increase our ability to charge more than the maximum \nrate.   Ideally they would like to eliminate the language I\'ve quoted above.  \nHowever, my research has indicated that absent our 1) bringing about radical \nchange in the way FERC thinks about recourse rates or 2) showing that TW \nlacks market power, we are probably stuck with this language.\n\nWhy the problem exists (you may already know):\n\nSteve Stojic and I did some looking into why the language is in our tariff in \nthe first place.  In the Alternative Rates Policy Statement (RM95-6-000), the \nCommission explained that it is willing to entertain individual requests for \nnegotiated rates, but only where customers retain the ability to choose a \ncost-of-service based tariff rates.  "[T]he availability of a recourse \nservice would prevent pipelines from exercising market power by assuring that \nthe customer can fall back to cost-based, traditional service if the pipeline \nunilaterally demands excessive prices or withholds service.  Thus, the \nrecourse rate mitigates market power."  \n\nThe Commission went on to confirmed that under ROFR provisions the highest \nrate that an existing shipper must match if it wishes to continue its \ntransportation arrangement is the maximum tariff rate. This policy is clearly \nnot limited to ROFR situations:  when capacity is constrained, a shipper \nwilling to pay only the recourse rate cannot lose access to capacity merely \nbecause someone else is willing to pay a negotiated rate.  "When there are \nmore requests for capacity than there is capacity available, then the \npipeline must allocate capacity among those shippers willing to pay either \nthe negotiated rate or the maximum recourse rate, for example on a pro rata \nbasis if required by its tariff."  The example cited by the Commission:  If a \npipeline has 100 Dth/d available and two shippers request that capacity, one \nwho is willing to pay no more than the recourse rate of $5 and another a \nnegotiated rate of $6, then each would be allocated 50 Dth/d on a pro rata \nbasis (assuming the tariff provided for pro rata allocation and not some \nother allocation method such as lottery).  \n\nWhen TW filed for authority to charge negotiated rates, it voluntarily added \nthe statement that "if the rate bid exceeds the maximum tariff rate, then the \nrate will be considered to be the maximum tariff rate."  Presumably we had \nconcluded that we needed to add this recourse rate related provision in order \nto receive negotiated rate authority.  \n\nSolutions??\n\nI would like to know whether you concur that changing our tariff language \noutright is probably out of the question.  I feel as if I\'ve really been \nchasing my tail here.  I have owed Lindy an answer for some time now.  But I \nkeep coming back to our having to prove lack of market power (which, Drew, is \nwhere I believe you were headed when we talked about this in mid-October).  \nSteve Harris has asked whether we can just start small and remove the \nrecourse rate cap as to only a portion of our system.  I think we would still \nhave to show lack of market power in order to do this.  Do you agree?  Stojic \nwarns that proving lack of market power is a lengthy and expensive \nproposition.  Might be worth it to us, though.\n\nAnother idea is to somehow provide shippers with an incentive to pay more \nthan max rate.  After all, we do have authority to charge negotiated rates.  \nWe\'ve seen one instance in which one of our marketers was able to get more \nthan max rates for IT space based on good customer relations alone.  However, \ndespite our wonderful relationships with most of our customers, it\'s unlikely \nwe can pull this off with any consistency.  We wondered whether we might be \nable to get more than max rates in the context of an auction procedure.  But \nI just am not convinced we could get around the Commission\'s requirement that \nrecourse rates be available.  That requirement has not changed.  Have either \nof you seen anything to the contrary?  \n\nI would like to meet with you two, plus several others I have in mind, to \ndiscuss this, preferably early this week (Tues. or Wed.), but would like to \ndiscuss briefly with you first.  Please call me so we can talk for a few \nminutes.  Thanks. \n\n\n\n \n\n', 1], ['September Basis Options', 'text/plain', 'Here you go Cynthia...\n\n\n\nSusan\n\n', 1], ['Every day needs a little dose of levity...', 'text/plain', 'Fifth grade assignment\n\nThe teacher gave her fifth grade class an assignment: \nGet their parents to tell them a story with a moral at \nthe end of it.
