I have no \ncomments.\n\nBest,\nJeff\n\n', 1], ['Re: CDWR Response to RFB', 'text/plain', "No comments.  Chris, I'll have the summary to you shortly.\n\nJeff\n\n", 1], ['Core/Noncore Plan Hits the Papers', 'text/plain', 'Plan would have biggest customers pay Edison\'s debt \nGreg Lucas, Sacramento Bureau Chief\nThursday, May 31, 2001 \n,2001 San Francisco Chronicle \nURL: \nhttp://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2001/05/31/M\nN231235.DTL \nSacramento -- Legislative leaders are drafting a new rescue plan for Southern \nCalifornia Edison that would put the utility back on its feet financially at \nthe expense of its biggest customers. \nThe plan would leave manufacturers, refineries and other big industrial \ncustomers with the burden of paying nearly all the utility\'s $3.5 billion \nback debt through a dedicated charge. Residential and small commercial users \nwould be on the hook for only a fraction of the back debt. \nBig users say it is unfair to saddle them with all of Edison\'s debt, but \nsupporters of the plan say it\'s these users that wanted deregulation and \nshould shoulder the costs it created. \n"We\'re trying to put something together in a way that solves all these \nproblems, and if people are to be pigheaded about it, we won\'t solve any \nproblems," said Assemblyman Fred Keeley, D-Boulder Creek (Santa Cruz County). \nAlthough the plan is an alternative to Gov. Gray Davis\' proposed deal to put \nEdison back on its feet financially, it could be used as a model to help \nrestore Pacific Gas and Electric Co. to solvency. \nDemocrats say the plan contains some elements desired by Republicans, but GOP \nlawmakers object to saddling large business users with Edison\'s debt. \nThe plan is based on the way gas customers are divided into "core" and \n"noncore" users. \nSEPARATING \'CORE\' USERS\nUnder this proposal, electrical users would be divided the same way. Core \nusers would be customers who use 500 kilowatts or less a month. Noncore would \nbe those using more than 500 kilowatts. \nOut of Edison\'s 4.2 million customers, only 3,600 would be noncore customers. \nBut those 3,600 customers use about 26 percent of Edison\'s demand for energy. \nCore customers would get their power from generators owned by Edison, long- \nterm contracts and alternative energy producers, such as wind farms and solar \npanels, on contract with the utility. \nThat would mean those customers would no longer be subject to the whims of \nthe spot market, which has far higher prices than other sources of \nelectricity. \nLarge users, the noncore customers, would be given the right to negotiate to \nbuy their power directly from generators or build on-site power plants to \nmake themselves energy self-sufficient. \nThe plan would be phased in through January 2003 to give large energy \ncustomers time to prepare for buying power on the open market. \nDuring that period, residential, small business and large industrial users \nwould all share in paying off Edison\'s debt. But in 2003, that burden would \nshift exclusively to the big users. \nRepublican lawmakers and those same large users have been clamoring to be \ngiven what is called "direct access" to generators so they can negotiate \ncheaper rates. \nEnron is also backing the idea of cutting loose the largest electricity users \nbecause that would create a built-in market for the energy the company sells. \nLarge users who want to remain on the grid could do so. \nEDISON \'ENCOURAGED\'\nSources said Edison officials met with lawmakers over the weekend to iron out \ndetails of the plan. \nA spokesman for Edison said he was "encouraged" by the talks. \n"I haven\'t seen a finished product or a plan," said Bob Foster, a senior vice \npresident with Edison. "They\'re approaching this in a spirit of goodwill and \ntrying to find a solution." \nBig businesses complain that the plan does not work because right now, there \nis nowhere they can buy cheap electricity. \n"We\'re very concerned that separating the core from the noncore means we will \nexperience extreme rate hikes over the next two years," said D.J. Smith, a \nlobbyist for the California Large Energy Consumers Association. \n"When you add blackouts, the multiple interruptions of production and another \npotentially huge rate hike, the result would be catastrophic to the economy," \nSmith said. \nAdded Dorothy Rothrock, a lobbyist for the California Manufacturers and \nTechnology Association: "What\'s the rationale for the noncore to be paying \nthe entire Edison undercollection? It sounds to me like just pure politics. \nThey don\'t want voters to pay because they vote." \nCONSUMER ADVOCATE SMELLS A RAT\nHarvey Rosenfield, head of the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights, \nsaid he thought the plan would eventually turn into a bailout as business \ninterests muscle lawmakers into pushing some portion of Edison\'s debt onto \nresidential and smaller commercial customers. \n"I think it\'s a trick. We\'ve seen this same tactic used at the Public \nUtilities Commission, where what were supposed to be rate increases for big \nbusiness end up costing more for residential and small businesses," \nRosenfield said. \nThe new plan also does not include the outright purchase of Edison\'s part of \nthe transmission system that loops electricity around the state. \nDavis backs buying the lines for $2.7 billion. Democrats have insisted that \nfor the state\'s financial help, taxpayers receive something of value. \nRepublicans have insisted that they will back no proposal that includes state \npurchase of transmission lines. \nIn the new proposal, the state would have a five-year option to buy the \ntransmission lines for $1.2 billion -- the book value of the asset. \nIn addition, the utility would make $1.5 billion available to the state to \neither purchase other assets -- such as Edison\'s hydroelectric facilities, \nfor example -- or use it in partnership to build new power plants. \nE-mail Greg Lucas at glucas@sfchronicle.com. \n,2001 San Francisco Chronicle ? Page?A - 5 \n\n', 1], ['Re: Electricity Deregulation', 'text/plain', "David:\nThanks so much.  I'd almost given up hope.  I will be distributing the \nproposal immediately and attempting to garner support industry-wide, across \nthe nation. Don't hesitate to \ncontact me to discuss it further.  415.782.7822.\n\nBest,\nJeff\n\n", 1], ['Update--Day  of California PUC Hearings', 'text/plain', 'The Commission closed the hearings last night at 7 PM.\nThe Commission refused all attempts by the utilities\'--and there were \nseveral--to get information on "ending the rate freeze" into the hearing \nrecord.\nThe Commission is attempting to get a draft decision out at 10 AM today (PST).\nIf it gets out, there will be oral argument at 12:30 today (PST), with final \ndecision issued tomorrow at the Commission\'s regularly scheduled business \nmeeting.\nIf it does not get out, there will be no oral argument, and the Commission \nwill issue its final decision tomorrow at its regularly scheduled business \nmeeting.\nAnything could happen but it appears at this point that the decision will \nonly address the need for a rate increase (rumors flyling furiously regarding \nhow high the increase will be), with "rate freeze" issues put off for another \nday in the near future.\nYesterday, the Governor of California joined Edison\'s suit against FERC \ncalling for region-wide, hard price caps.\n\n', 1], ['PUC DRAFT Decision', 'text/plain', "Copy of order to follow. I would appreciate your feedback.  The amendments would be as follows:\n\nCustomers who were on Direct Access when DWR started buying power (Jan. \n17th?), and are still on Direct Access when the bill passes, should be exempt \nfrom paying for the bonds. \n\nIn short, customers should not be forced to pay for power twice--once from \ntheir ESP, and once from DWR.  Since these customers receive power services \nfrom their ESP, they never consumed DWR power in the first place and it \nwouldn\'t be fair to require them to pay for it.\n\nCustomers who have been utility customers since DWR started buying power but \nsubsequently switched to Direct Access should only pay for power provided by \nDWR that they actually consumed, no more and no less.  \n\nFor example, if a customer was a utility customer when DWR started buying \npower but switched to Direct Access on May 1st, then the customer would only \nbe responsible for reimbursing DWR for power deliveries that took place from \nJan. 17th thru April 30th.\n\nI believe that we agreed on these concepts during the negotiations that took \nplace over the past 4-5 weeks.  Or if we didn\'t explicitly agree during the \ntalks, they seem to be principles on which we ought to be able to agree \npretty easily now. And rather than leave the issue hanging, which can create \nunnecessary and costly uncertainty for customers, I suggest that we include \nvery clear and simple legislative language in the bond bill clarifying what \ncustomers\' obligations are.  Your thoughts are appreciated.\n\nIn addition, we have talked quite a bit about providing customers with \nincentives in the attempt to get California out of the energy hole that it \nfinds itself in.  Providing (20KW and above) customers with an incentive to \nswitch to Direct Access as soon as possible could 1) reduce the net short \nposition that the state (and ultimately consumers) have to finance, thereby \nreducing spot purchases and price volatility,  2) reduce electricity \npurchasing costs, and 3) reduce the burden on the state budget.\n\nWith this in mind, I\'m also proposing that the group consider an amendment to \nthe bond bill that would exempt from bond charges any customer that switches \nto Direct Access by September 1st.\n\nFinally, it seems odd that the language directing the PUC to suspend Direct \nAccess is still in the bill.  If a dedicated rate component is created, that \nseems to eliminate altogether the need to suspend Direct Access.  And if \nthat\'s the case, would it make sense to delete that language from the bill?\n\nLook forward to your comments and working with you to get support for and \npassage of the "core/noncore" proposal.\n\nBest,\nJeff\n\n', 1], ['trip to NYC', 'text/plain', 'Hi.\n\nPlease book me SF/NYC round trip,leaving Tues 8.2.01 at 9:15 am, returning on \nsunday taking the 4:15 pm from NYC. Best, Jeff\n\n", 1], ['Soil Test for Growing Grapes', 'text/plain', "Greetings:\nLeft you a voicemail.  We spoke recently about getting a device to record \ntemperature on my property in Mendocino, where I'm hoping to grow a few \ngrapes.  Had a couple of questions about soil testing.  Could you give me a \ncall when you have a minute at 415.782.7822.  Greatly appreciated.\n\nBest,\nJeff\n\n", 1], ['State Senate OKs bailing out Edison from bankruptcy', 'text/plain', 'FYI.  Fairly accurate account of the activities in California.   Assembly \nreleased new version of Hertzberg\'s bill late last night.  Another update to \nfollow shortly. \n\nBest,\nJeff\n********************************************\n\nState Senate OKs bailing out Edison from bankruptcy \nAssembly plans own version for utility \nLynda Gledhill and Robert Salladay, Chronicle Sacramento Bureau\nSaturday, July 21, 2001 \n,2001 San Francisco Chronicle \nURL: http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2001/07/21/MN133267.DTL \nSacramento -- The state Senate approved a plan yesterday to keep Southern \nCalifornia Edison from falling into bankruptcy, but the bill crafted as an \nalternative to the pact between the utility and Gov. Gray Davis faces an \nuncertain future. \nThe bill by Democratic Sens. Richard Polanco of Los Angeles and Byron Sher of \nPalo Alto would give the state a five-year option to buy the utility\'s \ntransmission lines and would have the state guarantee no more than $2.5 \nbillion of the utility\'s debt. Edison amassed an estimated $3.5 billion in \ndebt as wholesale electricity prices increased but retail rates remained \nfrozen. \nThe Assembly was also attempting to craft its own version of a deal last \nnight, but political maneuvering and fears of repeating the same kind of \nmistakes that led to California\'s botched 1996 deregulation legislation \nhaunted lawmakers. \nDavis continued to apply pressure on lawmakers to put a bill on his desk \nbefore Aug. 15, a date set in the original agreement between Davis and \nEdison. \nLawmakers were scheduled to start their monthlong summer recess last night, \nbut failure to pass the state budget meant no one was leaving town. \n"It\'s a firm deadline, which means this issue has to be fully resolved prior \nto the end of the legislative recess," Davis said of the Aug. 15 date. \nDavis suggested that a conference committee or working group could be used to \niron out differences between the two bills, but it is unclear whether that \ncould be accomplished in the next few days. \n"I have problems with both bills," Davis said. "I am heartened by the fact \nthat there\'s a bill moving in each house." \nBoth houses struggled to garner enough votes to get their respective bills to \na floor vote, and many lawmakers indicated that they were not happy with the \nprocess. \nIn the Senate, 22 Democrats voted for the Edison plan, while four Democrats \nand all 13 Republicans voted no. \nSen. Jackie Speier, D-Hillsborough, said she would vote for the bill in its \ncurrent form, but not if any substantial changes are made. \n"The Legislature is ill-equipped to try to craft a deal," she said. "This \nparticular measure -- and only this one -- has the intent and clarity to \nprotect ratepayers. I\'m leery of the bill going to the Assembly and being \ncannibalized." \nThe Senate bill authorizes Edison to issue $2.5 billion in bonds to pay off \nalternative energy producers and their banks. The bonds would be paid off \nthrough increased rates charged Edison\'s largest customers and would not \ncover the $1 billion Edison owes out-of-state generators. \nEdison maintains that the Senate bill will not make the company creditworthy, \nwhich would put it back in the position of buying power. \nThe state has been spending upward of $50 million a day on power since \nJanuary, and Davis and lawmakers want the rescue plan in place so that the \nutility can once again begin buying power. There is also hope that any deal \nwould be used as a way to get Pacific Gas & Electric Co. out of bankruptcy. \nIn the Assembly, two competing measures put pressure on leaders to change \ntheir bill. The rescue plan by Assembly Speaker Robert Hertzberg of Sherman \nOaks and Assemblyman Fred Keeley, D-Boulder Creek, was undergoing changes to \ngarner more support. \nSome of the changes included eliminating the purchase of transmission lines \nand taking municipal utilities out of the deal. \nAssemblywoman Elaine Alquist, D-San Jose, one of the undecided members on the \nEdison agreement, said the original bill was too complex. \n"It\'s a cleaner bill," Alquist said. "I think it comes down to whether this \ndoes not affect our constituents and there is not a link to PG&E. I would say \nI\'m tentatively satisfied." \nAlquist and other Democrats said they were concerned about the rushed nature \nof the Edison negotiations. Only a few members of the Assembly -- all former \nstate senators now in the lower house -- voted to approve the 1996 \nlegislation, AB1890, that brought deregulation to California. \nAssemblyman Joseph Simitian, D-Palo Alto, said he gave a courtesy vote to the \nHertzberg-Keeley plan in the Appropriations Committee, in order to get the \nmeasure to the Assembly floor and continue debate. \n"As we\'ve learned from the experience of AB1890, the devil is in the details. \nI have a lot of questions," Simitian said. "The difficulty is that very \nlittle gets done here until there is a deadline, and then once there is a \ndeadline, too much gets done." \nHertzberg acknowledged that some Assembly members were afraid the bill was \ngetting rushed, but he said lawmakers are well-informed about the energy \ncrisis and its details. He said they have had 200 hours of caucus meetings \nand countless hearings on the crisis. \nA wild card in the Assembly\'s plan was a bill by Assemblyman Rod Wright, D- \nLos Angeles, that garnered Republican support. The so-called "straight \nbailout" would give Edison its $3.5 billion through a $2-a-month fee levied \non utility ratepayers. It was stuck in the Assembly Appropriations Committee. \nE-mail the reporters at lgledhill@sfchronicle.com and \nrsalladay@sfchronicle.com. \n,2001 San Francisco Chronicle ? In addition, it could=\n=20\nsave the state up to $1.3 billion in power costs by reducing the amount of=\n=20\nelectricity the state must buy during expensive summer peak periods.\n?=14 ?=01AThis program helps us take control of our own energy destiny,?=14=\n ?=0F_ Governor=20\nDavis said. ?=14 ?=01AWe will save money and reduce costs to consumers. The=\n 20/20=20\nprogram will save up to 2,200 megawatts during the summer peak period.=20\nThat?=14 ?=01vs power the state won?=14 ?=01vt have to purchase. Instead of=\n paying=20\nexorbitant rates to out-of-state generators, I?=14 ?=01vd rather pay Califo=\nrnia=20\nconsumers to conserve.?=14 ?=0F_=20\nThe voluntary program is designed to cover all households and businesses in=\n=20\nCalifornia. Under the Governor?=14 ?=01vs plan, customers will receive a 20=\n percent=20\nrebate on Summer 2001 bills if they achieve 20 percent or greater reduction=\n=20\nin electricity consumption between June and September versus last year.=20\nResidential and small commercial rebates will be based on 20 percent=20\nreduction of total=20\nconsumption, while commercial and industrial customer rebates will be based=\n=20\non 20 percent reduction of peak load.=20\nRebates will be issued at the end of the June-September period.\nThe 20/20 program for Summer 2001 is a major component of Governor Davis?=\n=14 ?=01v=20\ncomprehensive energy efficiency and demand reduction program. Since January=\n,=20\nGovernor Davis has instituted conservation measures to help Californians=20\nconserve energy, including:=20\nDirecting more than $800 million for programs to improve conservation and=\n=20\nefficiency.=20\nImplementing aggressive conservation measures in state buildings, resulting=\n=20\nin about 200 MW of savings during energy emergencies.=20\nDeveloping a comprehensive outreach and education campaign to reach=20\nbusinesses,=20\norganizations, and millions of California consumers.=20\nPartnering with other governmental entities, including school districts to=\n=20\nensure that all 475 cities, 58 counties, and 8,300 schools in California=20\nreduce consumption.=20\nAdopting the strongest energy efficiency standards in the world for=20\nresidential and non-residential buildings and appliances.=20\nIncorporating energy efficient, sustainable building designs in new state=\n=20\nbuilding projects.=20\nIssuing 15 Governor\'s Executive Orders on energy.=20\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPR01: 090\nFOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE\n03/13/2001 8:00 AM=20\n\nCALIFORNIA RECEIVES FIRST=20\nPEAKER POWER PLANT PROPOSALS\nSACRAMENTO=20\nGovernor Gray Davis announced that the first two proposals for power plants=\n=20\nto provide electricity at peak use times this summer have been received by=\n=20\nthe California Energy Commission.\n"We are doing everything we can to greatly streamline the time it takes to=\n=20\nget new generation up and running this summer," Governor Davis said. "These=\n=20\nnew peaker proposals are examples of our determination to meet California\'s=\n=20\nenergy challenge."\nA 90-megawatt plant called the Larkspur Energy Facility would be located in=\n=20\nthe Otay Mesa area of the City of San Diego, at the corner of Harvest Road=\n=20\nand Otay Mesa Road.=20\nThe second proposal is for the Indigo Energy Facility, a 135-megawatt plant=\n=20\nthat would be located near an existing wind generating facility in the City=\n=20\nof Palm Springs in Riverside County. The project is north of Interstate 10,=\n=20\non 19th Avenue, east of North Indian Avenue.=20\nBoth projects use natural gas-fueled simple-cycle turbine generators equipp=\ned=20\nwith state of the art air pollution control features. They are being propos=\ned=20\nby Wildflower Energy LP, a Houston, Texas-based company. The two projects a=\nre=20\npart of the Independent System Operator\'s reliability generation agreements=\n=20\nplanned to come on-line this summer.\nOn February 8, 2001, Governor Davis directed the Energy Commission to use i=\nts=20\nemergency power plant permitting authority to permit new peaking and=20\nrenewable power plants that can be on-line by July 31, 2001. The emergency=\n=20\npermitting authority extended to peaker projects that have ISO contracts an=\nd=20\nhave not begun the licensing process with the local jurisdictions. Peaker=\n=20\npower plants are simple cycle generators that can be constructed in a=20\nrelatively small area and can readily connect to the existing electricity=\n=20\ntransmission and natural gas system.=20\nThe Energy Commission review of the proposed projects will include site tou=\nrs=20\nand informational hearings in both local areas. Both applications are=20\ncurrently under review by Energy Commission staff for data adequacy. Once=\n=20\nthey are accepted as data adequate, the Energy Commission plans to expedite=\n=20\nthe licensing process under its emergency process to approve projects in as=\n=20\nsoon as 21 days.=20\nProvisions of the California Environmental Quality Act do not apply to=20\nemergency power plant projects.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n', 1], ['FW: SoCalGas Capacity Forum', 'text/plain', 'You get this? Gray Davis and other officials demanded $8.9 billion in refunds from the \ngenerators and brokers who have been selling California power for the past \nyear, alleging that California is, in Davis\' words, "being gouged and ripped \noff." But the number itself was more or less plucked out of thin air -- an \narithmetic exercise by the state power grid\'s traffic controller not intended \nfor a refund proceeding. And while Judge Curtis Wagner saw it as unrealistic, \nDavis and other state officials insisted on its validity. \n"There are refunds due that total hundreds of millions of dollars and maybe a \nbillion dollars," Wagner said as a final negotiating session collapsed. But \nthat\'s a far cry from the $8.9 billion that Davis insists is due. "If you \nthink California is going to settle for $1 billion in refunds, we will see \nyou in court," Davis said Tuesday. \nWhy is Davis being so belligerent? Because it\'s good politics. Ever since he \nbegan berating out-of-state generators and accusing them of ripping off \nCalifornia, Davis\' approval ratings have been climbing. If he settled for \nsubstantially less -- the power generators probably would agree to a couple \nof billion dollars to rid themselves of the matter -- Davis would be \nembarrassed. Politically, he\'s served by continuing to portray himself as \nfighting for California and against the out-of-state generators. \nThat it\'s more political construct than reality is indicated by another event \nthis week, Davis\' release of state power purchase data from early in the year \n-- numbers that were made public only because a judge told him he had to do \nit. \nDavis and his minions have been accusing Texas-based generators and power \nbrokers of particularly egregious price gouging -- clearly playing on \nCalifornians\' instinctive mistrust of anything Texan and implying that Texan \nGeorge W. Bush is a co-conspirator. But the power purchase records -- which \nwere released only to journalists willing to pay a stiff fee -- indicate that \nless than 10 percent of California\'s power purchase dollars were going to \nTexas and the private sellers, in general, charged the state less than such \npublicly owned utilities as the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power. \nThe clearly adverse position being taken by FERC and the purchase data that \nundercut his jingoistic sloganeering are not, however, deterring Davis from \ncontinuing to operate, at least for public consumption, in the melodramatic \nvirtual world. \nOne cannot, however, ignore reality forever. The likelihood of a \npro-generator decision from FERC means that there will be no easy out for \nDavis, or for his pending deal to prevent Southern California Edison from \nslipping into bankruptcy court. The Legislature has refused to act on the \nEdison rescue plan while it awaited an indication of whether the utility\'s \ndebts would be slimmed down by FERC. \nThis week\'s farcical events make it more likely that the Edison deal will \nstall out permanently in the Legislature and its creditors will force the \nutility into bankruptcy court later this summer. That\'s part of that nasty \nold reality that cannot simply be wished away. \n\nThe Bee\'s Dan Walters can be reached at (916) 321-1195 or dwalters@sacbee.com\n.\n\n\n\n\n', 1], ["Rick's Panel", 'text/plain', 'Plz see email. Power delivery efficiency questioned: Output at', 'text/plain', 'FYI.  David Freeman and DWR....public power working for California.\n********************************************************\nPower delivery efficiency questioned: Output at low-cost generating plants \nhas been cut while costlier ones continue to operate.\nBy Carrie Peyton\nBee Staff Writer\n(Published July 31, 2001) \nCalifornia is sometimes deliberately cutting output from low-cost power \nplants while running more expensive ones, utility and grid officials say. \nThe sporadic episodes haven\'t cost much yet, but they illustrate a \npotentially troubling disconnect in the system that has quickly grown between \ntwo agencies that help deliver electricity to a power-strapped state. \n"We seem to be building this inefficiency into the system, and it doesn\'t \nseem to be getting better," said Mike Florio, a consumer advocate who sits on \nthe governing board of the Independent System Operator. \nThe trouble is that the ISO, created in 1996 to manage the power grid in a \nderegulated electric market, tries to run the grid by auctions that -- in \ntheory -- provide the cheapest electricity for the state\'s consumers. \nMeanwhile, the state Department of Water Resources, which in January stepped \nin to buy power on behalf of cash-strapped utilities, isn\'t bidding at some \nauctions because it believes it can provide cheaper power if it doesn\'t. \n"We have an inefficient market and an inept government entity. It\'s sort of \nthe worst of both worlds," Florio said, criticizing his agency and the DWR. \nISO staffers decline to discuss the situation in detail, saying it involves \nconfidential bidding behavior. \nBut Pete Garris, chief of operations for the power-buying arm of the \nDepartment of Water Resources, confirmed that the ISO has been asking his \nagency to take part in more auctions, but the state has declined. \nThe state\'s role is to buy electricity for customers of utilities whose \ncredit was no longer good enough to buy on their own, he said. \n"We\'re not in it to do those kinds of marketing functions," he said. "It\'s \nnot necessarily a good fit." \nSome of the ISO auctions are used to lessen congestion on transmission lines. \nOthers are used to stabilize the grid by slightly increasing or decreasing \noutput when demand doesn\'t match forecasts. \nGenerally, the highest-cost power plants should be the ones cutting back, a \nprocess the industry calls "decking." \nBut since May, on ISO orders, Southern California Edison has repeatedly \nthrottled back on the Mohave Generating Station, which produces some of the \ncheapest power available to California today, costing as little as $10 to $20 \na megawatt-hour. \nEdison, which owns a majority share of Mohave, has cut its output by 5,660 \nmegawatt-hours between May and July, about one-half of 1 percent, at the \nISO\'s behest, according to data Edison provided to The Bee. \nThe ISO could probably have saved the state\'s consumers $370,000 at one plant \nif it had asked a higher-cost gas-burning plant to cut back instead of \nMohave, a coal-burning workhorse in Laughlin, Nev., Florio said. \nThe amount sounds like "small potatoes," but in some ways it is more alarming \nthan the $14 million the state lost recently by selling excess power for less \nthan it paid, he said. \nIndustry experts agree that such below-cost sales are common in a business \nwhere power needs fluctuate dramatically based on the weather. \nBy contrast, "this is a dead weight loss. Higher costs are being incurred for \nno good reason," Florio said. \n"The question is, why is the ISO calling on Mohave and not (cheaper) gas \nplants? The answer is, the gas plants aren\'t bidding ... probably because \nthey\'re contracted with DWR," he said. \nFour Corners, another low-cost coal plant partly owned by Edison, has also \nbeen throttled back at ISO request, Edison officials said. \nIn addition, so few bidders have shown up at ISO auctions to ease stress on \ntransmission lines that the system has fallen into disarray, with the ISO \ninstead ordering across-the-board power production cuts that are boosting \ncosts, Florio said. \nFor its part, the ISO will say only that "we are making the most economical \ndecisions we can based on the bids available," said spokeswoman Stephanie \nMcCorkle. \nDWR\'s Garris said the state and the ISO have been meeting repeatedly on \nbidding and other coordination issues, and he hopes to have a \nsmoother-running system in place by next summer. \n\n\nThe Bee\'s Carrie Peyton can be reached at (916) 321-1086 or \ncpeyton@sacbee.com <mailto:cpeyton@sacbee.com>.\n\n', 1], ['Re: FW: RE: Legislative Report (07/05/2001) -- IEP', 'text/plain', "i'd send to the big list.  i used to send what julie malinowski sent around.\n\n", 1], ['Year End Ratings', 'text/plain', "In order for me to effectively represent you at the ETS PRC  and for some of \nyou at the Accounting and Finance PRC's I will need some information from \neach of you. Some of ENA's trading parties cannot satisfy this exemption from \nregulation because they are not a producer/merchant handling the underlying \ncommodity (such as banks, hedge funds, etc) even though they may be entering \ninto the transaction for business purposes.  If that situation occurs, ENA \nMUST ALWAYS BE THE OFFEREE OF THE OPTION (as buyer or seller) and ENA cannot \nsolicit the party to enter into the transaction.\n\nIf ENA's trading partner fails to satisfy the Trade Option Exemption, our \nconfirmation will EXPLICITLY state that ENA was offered the option to buy or \nsell by the counterparty.\n\nPlease call me if you have any questions. If the swap is 4/4.5, one a day up, and someone buys half a day, \nmaking the market, 4/4.5 one a day by half a day, the size offered on a 10 \ncent out of the money call might be as low as 30 contracts, a much smaller \nsize than most people want to trade.  If we restrict to strikes with a lower \ndelta, we face the problem of not offering enough strikes and not making a \nmarket in options that have open EOL interest that have moved closer to the \nmoney.  \nMaybe the answer is to assume the swap hedge to be a penny wide two way \nwrapped around the EOL swap mid market.  Thus if the front swap on EOL is \n4/4.5 one a day by half a day,  the input into the option calculator is \n3.75/4.75, 100 up.  In this case I think 100 is necessary because once a \nstrike has open interest, we must continue to support it.  Thus I anticipate \nhaving to make markets in deep itm options as the market moves.\n\nIn terms of straddle strikes, I think the edge received from buying straddles \nstruck on the EOL offer and vice-versa is not big enough to compensate for \nwhat I think the industry will view as a scam and another way Enron is trying \nto rip people off.  Although striking on the mid-market is probably easier \nfor the trader, I actually think striking in five cent increments makes more \nsense.  It allows people to trade out of the position on EOL.  Whereas if \nsomeone buys the 3085 straddle and the market moves to 3200, they have to \ncall ENE to close the trade.  If the trade is struck at 3100, we will have a \nmarket on both the 3100 call and put at all times.  Secondly, I would \nanticipate non-volatility driven option traders may elect to sell either just \nthe put or call in this scenario depending on their view of market direction.\n\n', 1], [None, 'text/plain', "We will open EOL 4-7 on Monday for everyone's trading pleasure.\n\n", 1], [None, 'text/plain', 'greg:\nwhat is the (correct) formula you devised for profitability on last trade is \nmid?\n\n', 1], ['re:summer inverses', 'text/plain', "a couple more thoughts.  certainly losing lots of indutrial demand both to \nswitching and slowdown in economy. There are a couple isolated products that \nEnron does not do a good job of valuing because of systems limtations.  This \nwas one product.  Our spread options are booked in Excel using option pricing \nmodels created by the research group.  The problem with these models is that \nthey are strictly theoretical and don\'t take into account gas fundamental \nprice limitations.  For instance, it is less probable, though not impossible, \nfor a transport spread from a production area to a market area to go within \nvariable cost than the models predict.  Thus it is necessary to apply a \ncorrelation skew curve on top of the overlying correlation used.  Obviously, \nwe have this function in our pricing models.  I was not aware this \nmethodology had not been transferred to the valuation models.  This has since \nbeen changed.  Fortunately these incidents tend to be extremely rare as very \nfew non-investment grade companies trade these types of products.  \n\nFinally, on Friday Bill wanted to do a trade that reduced his exposure to \nEnron. (Nasdaq: TIBX -\nnews), a leading provider of real-time infrastructure software for \ne-business, announced today Network Appliance, Inc. As a \nfast growing company, Network Appliance has been continually implementing\nbest-in-class enterprise systems such as enterprise resource planning, \ncustomer resource management, human resources and manufacturing applications.\nTo integrate these disparate systems and ensure that the right people within \nNetwork Appliance have access to the information they need, Network\nAppliance turned to TIBCO.\n\n``We need an integration tool that will not only enable us to share \ninformation internally, but will also enable us to extend access to this \ninformation beyond\nour corporate firewalls, as we expand our e-commerce capabilities,'' said Ric \nMcCormick, director of business applications for Network Appliance.\n``TIBCO's proven e-business solutions provide us with the scalability, \nsecurity and reliability we need to ensure that our technology infrastructure \ncan\nkeep up with our business growth, and just as important, that our vital \nbusiness processes not be disrupted as we continue to implement new \nsolutions.''\n\n``To be successful e-businesses, companies need a highly efficient \ninformation infrastructure that connects every system and process in the \nenterprise,''\nsaid Fred Meyer, vice president of product management for TIBCO Software. \n``TIBCO ActiveEnterprise is helping leading companies like Network\nAppliance further leverage their front-end and back-end IT systems and bring \nthose systems closer to customers and partners over the Web.''\n\nAbout TIBCO ActiveEnterprise\n\nThe core of TIBCO's real-time software infrastructure offering is the TIBCO \nActiveEnterprise suite, designed for building a complete, end-to-end\nInternet and enterprise infrastructure that successfully scales to the most \ndemanding business information networks. It provides a real-time e-business\nintegration platform that encompasses data integration and transformation, \nbusiness process coordination, messaging, enterprise portals and alerting,\nadapters for legacy, packaged and third-party applications, plus enterprise \nmonitoring and management.\n\nAbout Network Appliance\n\nNetwork Appliance, Inc., a veteran in network file serving and caching, has \nbeen providing data access solutions since 1992, and is a member of both the\nS+P 500 and Nasdaq 100 index. Major corporations and ISPs, including Lycos, \nYahoo!, Citicorp Securities, Siemens, Lockheed, Cisco, Motorola, and\nTexas Instruments have deployed NetApp solutions. NetApp Internet caching \nsolutions (NetCache(TM) appliances) and file servers (filers) deliver fast,\nsimple, reliable, and cost-effective access to network-stored data and enable \nsimultaneous shared file services for UNIX, Windows NTc, and the World\nWide Web.\n\nThe company pioneered the concept of the ``network appliance,'' an extension \nof the industry trend toward dedicated, specialized products that perform\na single function. Network Appliance filers and NetCache appliances are based \non the company's innovative data access software known as the Data\nONTAP(TM) operating system and standards-compliant hardware.\n\nAbout TIBCO Software\n\nTIBCO Software Inc. is a leading provider of real-time e-business \ninfrastructure software. TIBCO's products enable the real-time distribution of\ninformation through patented technology called The Information Busc, or TIBc. \nTIB technology was first used to digitize Wall Street and has since been\nadopted in diverse industries including telecommunications, electronic \ncommerce, manufacturing and energy. 'http://clickathomepilot.enron.com\n\n', 1], ['transportation markets', 'text/plain', "riday July 7, 11:43 am Eastern Time\n\nCompany Press Release\n\nSOURCE: Columbia Gas Transmission\n\nColumbia Gas Transmission Files Innovative Capacity Auction\nProcess With FERC\n\nFAIRFAX, Va., July 7 /PRNewswire/ -- Continuing its quest to promote creative \nregulatory policies, Columbia Gas Transmission, a wholly owned\nsubsidiary of Columbia Energy Group, has urged the Federal Energy Regulatory \nCommission to consider an interactive, Internet-based pipeline capacity\nauction process that enhances Columbia's current open auction process.\n\nIn a first of its kind filing, Columbia proposes a ``bid/offer'' system for \nselling capacity similar to on-line natural gas commodity trading systems. \nThe filing\nwas made in response to customer concerns with the current process and is \nconsistent with sentiments expressed in FERC's Order 637, which\nencourages companies to voluntarily submit ``new and innovative approaches'' \nto capacity auctions. Since the filing is not required under Order 637,\nColumbia's proposed auction is separate from Columbia's Order 637 compliance \nfiling made June 15.\n\n``Under the current mechanism, capacity is not always awarded to the party \nthat places the highest value on it,'' said Carl Levander, vice-president of\nRates and Regulatory Policy for Columbia Gas Transmission. ``Even though we \nconduct our current capacity auction over a five-day period, parties often\nwait until the last 15 minutes to place a bid. Also, since the current \nprocess is based on set time periods, customers often call us back after the \nauction is\nclosed saying they valued the capacity greater than the winning bid.''\n\nAccording to Levander, Columbia's proposal addresses these concerns by moving \nto an enhanced, Internet-based interactive auction that takes into\nconsideration such current market conditions as daily fluctuations in \ncapacity value and the increased level of auction activity due to shorter-term\ncontracts.\n\nUnder Columbia's proposed ``bid/offer'' system, Columbia would ``offer'' (via \nits electronic bulletin board) sales terms for all its available firm \ncapacity.\nCustomers can then match all asking sales terms for any portion of the \nquantity and a sale is immediate and binding. If Columbia offers discounted\ncapacity, the customer can counter-offer with a different rate. Or, if \nColumbia offers maximum rate capacity, then a customer can counter-offer with \na\ndifferent term length. Columbia can match the highest bid, subject to a \npresent value process, and the sale is immediate and binding. At any time \nbefore a\nbinding sale, the customer can change or withdraw its bid.\n\nColumbia's ``bid/offer'' auction proposal meets the six basic principles \noutlined in FERC's Order 637. \n\n    *     Columbia's auction has predictable timing since the auction will\n          begin each day at 9:15 a.m. (EST) and all available capacity will be\n          posted prior to 8:00 a.m. (EST).\n    *     The auction will be open to all creditworthy bidders on a non-\n          discriminatory basis.\n    *     The auction is user-friendly since it will use Columbia's existing\n          EBB format. All information concerning rules and procedures will be\n          made available on the Internet.\n    *     The method of selecting the best bid will be easily understood since\n          bidders will only be able to change one variable with respect to\n          each capacity package made available.\n    *     As is Columbia's current practice, winning bids and the bidder's\n          identity will be posted to permit monitoring of how the selection\n          criteria were applied.\n    *     The bidding process will be transparent to all parties since all\n          bids (without the bidder's identity) will be available for review to\n          all bidders through an Internet-based system.\n\n\n``We believe the combination of these factors will ensure that the capacity \nauction format is 'transparent, verifiable, and non-discriminatory' to all \nparties\nas well as innovative in design,'' Levander said.\n\nLevander said the proposal not only meets the Commission's principles, it is \nbased on feedback gathered from customers, who expressed a desire for\ntransparent market information; shorter auction periods; an ability to \nwithdraw and change bids; and a real-time, immediate closure process.\n\nColumbia Gas Transmission, with offices in Charleston, W.Va., and Fairfax, \nVa., moves an average of three billion cubic feet of natural gas per day to\nmarkets along a 12,550-mile pipeline network, which reaches across 10 \nMidwestern, Northeastern and mid-Atlantic states. The company operates one\nof the largest natural gas storage systems in the country with over 240 \nbillion cubic feet (Bcf) of working capacity.\n\nColumbia Energy Group, based in Herndon, Va., is one of the nation's leading \nenergy services companies, with assets of approximately $7 billion. Its\noperating companies engage in nearly all phases of the natural gas business, \nincluding exploration and production, transmission, storage and distribution,\nas well as retail energy marketing, propane and petroleum product sales, and \nelectric power generation. Information about Columbia Energy Group\n(NYSE: CG - news) is available on the Internet at \nhttp://www.columbiaenergygroup.com. \n\nSOURCE: Columbia Gas Transmission \n\n                                      Email this story - View most popular \nstories emailed\n\n\n More Quotes and News:\n                     Columbia Energy Group (NYSE:CG - news)\n Related News Categories: government, internet, oil/energy, utilities\n\n\n\n                                                               Help\n\n\n                               Copyright , 2000 Yahoo! Paper fro Kevin K.\n2. Rosemary  at ICBI\nAndy kalotay\nBrad Horn\nJohansen\nPiazze\n\n', 1], [None, 'text/plain', 'http://www.x10.com/home/offer.cgi?!BF1,../bluefish21c.htm?>bf021\n\n', 1], ['Option Valuation', 'text/plain', "John,\n\nI think the crucial distinction is between recognition of risks and \nelimination of\nrisks through hedges (as correctly pointed out  in other messages). Being \naware of risk\ndoes not mean that one does not want to be compensated for it.\n\nNow a few more detailed comments.\n\n1. I think that illiquidity discount represents double counting when combined \nwith \na project finance discount rate. Illiquidity discount, in my view,\nshould be applied to financial options that trade in a market without \nsufficient depth.\nOne should apply a haircut if liquidating  a position takes a long time. The \napproach used in valuation\nof the Turkish transaction is the same as approach used in valuation of \ninvestments in physical\nassets, which are by definition illiquid. This illiquidity  is recognized \nthrough other aspects\nof valuation technology used in RAROC. \n\nIf we apply an illiquidity correction in this case, we should be consistent \nand use\nthis approach  across the board for all project finance type cases (not that \nI recommend this course of action).\n\n2. Valuation of an unheadgable options.\n\nLet's look at it from the position of a seller of the option.\n\nHe cannot hedge a short call or put and Black-Scholes valuation becomes the \nfloor for\nthe valuation: the seller has to be compensated for taking a price risk (as \nopposed to taking a vol\nrisk when he hedges). The issue of the compensation he will require becomes \nfuzzy.\nThe option really becomes an insurance type product and pricing depends on \ntwo factors:\n\n1. risk preference\n2. existing portfolio positions\n\nRisk preference. Insurance companies typically require a payment that \nconsists of two parts:\nexpected loss + unexpected loss. The latter is typically defined as 1 to 2 \nstandard deviations.\nThe number of  standard deviations depends on risk appetite and the ability \nto absorb the loss.\nI admit that it is a bit fuzzy, but this is the way the world works. We \nlooked into insurance pricing at the\nrequest of Jere Overdyke. You can talk to Vasant Shanbhogue to find out more \nabout it.\n\nExisting portfolio positions. An additional contract may increase or decrease \nthe risk of the overall portfolio.\nI would expect the deal to provide some risk diversification, but it does not \nlook to me as a deal that reduces risk\n(given all our positions in this region).\n\nWhat are the practical implications? Pricing depends on risk appetite (the \nutility function of a decision maker\nin technical jargon) and becomes to some degree arbitrary. \n\nIf we are short an option embedded in a deal and the option cannot be hedged,\nwe should subtract from the value of the contract\nthe value of the option (that is greater than the Black - Scholes value).\nIf we don't price this option explicitly,\nthe valuation of a contract will be based on a discount rate with a risk \npremium.\n\nIn the case of an option buyer, the situation is reversed. If he cannot \nhedge, he should recognize the risk\nof losing the value of his investment and apply a discount to the value of \nthe option.\nHow big is the discount? See the comments above. \n\nIn the special case, where hedging is possible and the Black-Scholes-Merton \nparadigm applies, both values\nwill become equal (ignoring transaction costs). The values of an option form \nthe point of view of \na seller and a buyer will converge.\n\n3. What happens in case we use simulation technology?\n\nWe can discount at the risk free rate along each scenario (each scenario will \nrecognize the downside and/or\nupside at different points in time in different states of the world).\nIf we run a sufficient number of scenarios, we shall get a distribution of \nNPV as of today.\nKnowing this distribution means that we can estimate risk, but in most cases \nwe are still holding\nit. The expected value should be, therefore, adjusted for risk. This is \nequivalent to using a \ndiscount rate with a risk premium.\n\nI hope this helps. Please, call me with additional questions. Sorry for a \ndelay in responding\nto this question. I ran my response by Stinson and Vasant, to make sure we \nall agree.\nIt's a very complicated technical problem and the financial theory does not \nhave\ngood answers.\n\n \n\nVince\n\n", 1], [None, 'text/plain', ' Liz Purcell\n\n\n\nPhone: (713) 582 3707\n\n', 1], ['Lunch', 'text/plain', "Bjorn,\n\nLet's meet 11:30 at the lobby. My cell phone  number\nis 713 410 5396,  just in case.\n\nDo you want me to make reservations? Historically, we were rather passive customers of\nthe academic institutions, trying to hire the best students and limiting our \npresence\non the campuses mostly to the recruiting trips and campus receptions.\n\nWe should rethink the way we work  with universities. The efforts to get \nthe best students look more and more like a hand-to-hand combat and often we \nare not\nvery successful. It is critical that we increase our presence on the campuses\nand this can be accomplished in a number of different ways:\n\n1. Involvement in research projects. For  example, we are currently  \nunderwriting two research\nprojects at Stanford University, involving  Ph.D. students of Professor  \nNicholas Bambos\n(a top expert on communications networks). We shall participate in formulation\nof the projects' objectives and will be given access to the results.\nInvolvement in research projects allows us to obtain \naccess to current scientific developments in the leading universities and \nalso to lock-up some very\npromising students. Most companies in the high tech industries have such \nprograms.\n\n2. Lectures and presentations by Enron employees. Practically every \npresentation\nI have made so far at different universities resulted in a number of resumes \nand hiring decisions.\nIt is important that students get exposed to Enron early in their academic \nprogram. In many cases,\nthe best students have already made up their mind by the time we approach \nthem during their \nsenior years.\n\n3. Visits by faculty members in Enron. \n\nCloser cooperation with the universities has many advantages in addition to \ngetting the best students\nand obtaining access to current research. The universities are very important \nin shaping public  opinion\non the issues critical to Enron's future (especially in the area of \nderegulation and design of new markets).\n\nCurrently, the relationships with many leading academic centers depend on \npersonal commitment of a number\nof overworked Enron employees. Thanks\n\nMike\n\n', 1], ['SOCAL', 'text/plain', 'Dear Tom, \n\nEnron would be interested in getting together with other trading partners to \ndiscuss listing other index points at the Socal border.  I think the market \nrequires other postings to reflect the fundamental changes in the market with \nrespect to transportation constraints.  The market has clearly seen a \ndivergence in the summer spreads between PG&E and Socal interconnects.  The \nmarginal generation load in SP-15 and Southern California this summer has \nproven that Socal Gas is short delivered gas and is incapable of meeting \ndaily demand with flowing supplies, and will be incapable of injecting gas \nduring these months.  Because of this, supply being transported from the \nSouthwest supply basins can only find a home going into PG&E.  This places \ndownward pressure on PG&E Topock gas and upward pressure on Socal Topock \ngas.  Remember, Socal is an island, not because of the delivered capacity to \nthe border via EPNG and TW, but because of the limited capacity of Socal\'s \ninterconnects.  Demand exceeds the supply interconnect capacity.   \n\nThere is also a divergence between Ehrenberg and Topock because of \nliquidity.  Topock is a more liquid market because of the upstream transport \ncontracts on EPNG and downstream buying patterns of certain Socal markets. \nThe market is more diversified at Topock than Ehrenberg.  The overwhelming \ndemand pressure on Socal gets exposed at Topock.  Although Ehrenberg is the \nmarginal point for gas into Socal, there is more of an imbalance in upstream \ncapacity (EPNG and TW) to downstream capacity (Socal Topock 545,000/d) at \nSocal Topock than at Ehrenberg.  The Socal Ehrenberg interconnect has 1.1 bcf \nof capacity and is primarily sourced by one market transporter.  Ehrenberg \nsimply gets placed at "market prices" because of varying objectives.  One \ntransporter may place gas to larger buyers to ensure flows, while smaller \nbuyers on Socal may not approach this transporter for supplies.  This \nilliquidity has led to a spread existing between Topock and Ehrenberg. \n\nPicture  the market, San Juan gas is trading well below the Permian and Waha \nbasins, which happen to be the marginal supply points for the west.  Because \nof the of the limited capacity going into Socal Topock, every transporter on \nEPNG and TW wants to fill their contracts with San Juan gas first.  These \nmolecules compete for Buyers at a limited delivery interconnect. Likewise, \nall Buyers reach out for supply coming through a limited delivery \ninterconnect (Topock). The San Juan then trys to find an outlet going east on \nthe SJ east leg of EPNG.  This transport leg simply displaces Permian gas \ngoing into Plains North and allows Permian gas to head west to Ehrenberg on \nthe EPNG south mainline.  While the Socal market peaks in the summer, so does \nthe EOC demand.  Permian west (Keystone West meter)  cannot satisfy both the \nEOC demand and the Socal demand.  So for the first time ever, we saw EPNG \nWaha West at maximum capacity to source transport contracts on the EPNG south \nmainline.  This tells the entire story.  When demand exceeds all available \nhistorical supply points, and begins to reach to Waha to meet Ehrenberg \ndemand, you have a paradigm shift.   This eliminates any correlation that may \nhave existed between the supply basins and the market area.  When Keystone \nWest reaches maximum capacity, the rule of market spreads not exceeding the \nmax rate transport rate then dies a fast death.  There is simply no available \ncapacity at the Keystone West meter to allow a shipper to buy max rate \ntransport on EPNG and ship it to Socal.  If you asked the market what the \nmaximum interconnect capacity at Keystone West is, 9 out of 10 would not \nknow.  This leads to blaming market participants for wide spreads that are \nabove historical levels.  It is like Al Gore blaming "big oil companies" for \nthe high prices of gas, when all refineries are at maximum capacity.  There \nsimply isn\'t the capacity to meet demand.  The supply exists, but there isn\'t \nenough refining capacity available to meet demand.  Fundamentals rule the \nmarket in all cases.\n\nI would like to propose the following index points for the Southern \nCalifornia border.  The market would  be better served with supply being \nincluded in these index points.  One, Socal CA production/Socal storage/EPNG \nEhrenberg, Two, Topock TW and EPNG, Three, KRS/Wheeler Ridge.  The market \nwill be experiencing more changes with respect to the Socal restructuring in \nthe future.  We will then address the different interconnects and propose an \nindex for the Socal citygate as well. \n\nCall me on Monday to discuss the Enron Online download.\n\nSincerely,   \n\nMike Grigsby\nDirector of West Trading\n713-780-1022\n\n', 1], ['Re: Sailing Update', 'text/plain', 'Yes, I will be out of town on the fourth. Late in Tommy Tuberville's first season as \nhead coach, the team was fractured, divided by the stress of almost two years \nof trouble, despair and losing.\n\n\n\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n--\n\nMore Auburn football | Talkin' Tigers Forum \n\n------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n--\n''It was defense and offense,'' offensive tackle Kendall Simmons said. \n''Whatever happened, we pointed fingers at each other.''\nOn the Friday night before last November's game against Central Florida, a \nsmall group of players gathered at the team hotel at the urging of fullback \nHeath Evans. They prayed. They talked about life and the sometimes bitter \nturns it can take.\n\nA bond began to grow among players young and old, black and white, starters \nand reserves. It wasn't so much about winning and losing or even about \nfootball. It was about matters of the heart.\n\n''We may have had 15-20 guys show up that first night,'' senior whip \nlinebacker Rob Pate said. ''Since then, it's just like another thing on the \nitinerary. It's not mandatory, but we have basically the whole team there. \nWe've got five or six coaches. Coach Tuberville comes in there. People just \nlay out their hearts, whatever is on their minds.''\n\nAuburn has won seven of the eight games it has played since that November \nnight. Players say they've done it with trust and a unity of purpose that has \ngrown ever stronger.\n\nIt has carried the 15th-ranked Tigers to a 5-0 record going into Saturday's \nSoutheastern Conference West Division showdown at 20th-ranked Mississippi \nState.\n\nPate says they'll go firm in the belief that they can count on each other in \nthe most difficult times.\n\nPate knows about pain and even fear. A mysterious disease, now seemingly \nunder control, threatened his senior season.\n\n''When you see a guy at his weakest point and he's reaching out asking you \nfor help, you know everything about a guy,'' Pate said. ''With me, it was my \nhealth. Before the first game, they set a chair in the middle of the room and \nevery guy in there put his hands on me. We said a prayer together. Man, I was \ncrying.\n\n''It's like that every weekend. Somebody on this team is suffering through \nsomething. They share it. When you line up on Saturday, it's a lot easier to \nlook at that person and know he is going to give it everything he's got.''\n\nOn the field, there has been little but happiness for Auburn this season. \nTuberville says it started when Auburn players, strengthened by the bad \ntimes, put aside their differences and their individual desires to play for \ntheir teammates and their school.\n\n''I've never been around a team this close,'' Tuberville said. ''They get \nalong. We haven't always played as great as we wanted to, but we've had guys \nurging the younger players and younger players pulling for the older guys to \nget better.\n\n''It's just a special group. They enjoy being around each other and \nunderstand what it's going to take for us to win.''\n\nThe change from not so long ago is striking, Simmons says.\n\n''If you don't really know each other and everybody is in their own little \ngroup, things aren't going to work,'' Simmons said. ''If you have trust in \nyour teammates, you can build a good team. Right now, we've got that going.''\n\nIt starts with the seniors, who have seen the good and the bad of college \nfootball. They went to the SEC Championship Game as freshmen in 1997. Then \ncame two losing seasons and the resignation of their head coach, Terry Bowden.\n\nThey revel in their success, yet they know it can be ever so fleeting. They \ntake pride in the closeness of a team on the way back.\n\nNo one understands better than fifth-year senior quarterback Ben Leard. He \nwent from starter to third team in 1998, then won his job back in 1999 when \nhardly anyone thought he could.\n\nToday, he has the highest efficiency rating of any SEC quarterback.\n\n''We have been practicing since August and we have yet to hear anyone say \n'Man, I'm looking forward to playing in the NFL,' '' Leard said. ''No one is \nworried about their personal accolades or how they are doing status-wise. \nEverybody just wants to win ball games. The relationships we have on this \nteam are like brothers.''\n\nLeard says nothing that happens can change that.\n\n''If we lose every game from now on, this will be one of the most special \nseasons I've ever had in my life,'' Leard said. ''We've got people excited. \nWe're excited. The fun is back in it for us.\n\n''It's a great feeling to be able to almost look forward to coming to \npractice, to see the guys, to have fun and talk. There are no fingers being \npointed anywhere. There are no individuals on this football team.''\n\nEvans was one who showed the way, happily accepting the unglamorous role of \nblocker for tailback Rudi Johnson. Every Friday night, Evans is still the one \nwho leads his teammates as they share their joy and their pain.\n\n''Heath is just like that all the time,'' Pate said. I have a few comments, and invite Pat Mackin to add \nany he may have, in particular based on his review of Section 4.14.\n\nIn Section 4.7(c)(iv), there is a reference to any contract obligations.  I \nbelieve this would include employment contracts, which do not appear to be \nidentified specifically on any schedule unless the annual amount exceeds \n$250K.    We may want to clarify that the disclosures are consistent with the \nprovisions of Section 4.13(iii).\n\nSection 4.8 provides that we will not enter into any employee benefits not \nrequired by law.  However, given that closing is pushed out so far in the \nfuture, we may want the flexibility to provide incentive bonuses for key \npersonnel to stay with the company through closing.  This may be done with \nthe Buyer\'s consent, but we may be tying our hands.  Section 6.2(e) contains \na similar restriction on making payments to officers/directors.\n\nIn addition, Section 4.8 states that we won\'t enter into or amend any \nemployment contracts.  We do not renew employment contracts at a single time, \nand the contracts of key personnel may expire.  Do we want to tie our hands \nand be prohibited from amending/extending the agreements?  Section 6.2(l) \nalso prohibits the modification/amendment of contracts with employees.\n\nIn Section 4.10, the wording "(other than Environmental Laws)" suggests that \nwe are not in compliance with environmental laws.  Rephrasing that sentence \nto refer to the provision of the Agreement may be preferable.\n\nIn Section 4.11(d), we promise that we haven\'t provided any gift of any kind \nto customers.  I don\'t think we can say that, given that we regularly host \nclient development outings (e.g. Rodeo BBQ tickets, golf tourneys, etc.) and \nprovide Enron goodies to people all the time. Is this\n true?\n   A:  Your heart is only good for so many beats, and that\'s it. Everything\n  wears out eventually. Speeding up your heart will not make you live\n longer;\n  that\'s like saying you can extend the life of your car by driving it\n  faster.  Want to live longer? Take a nap.\n\n   Q: Should I cut down on meat and eat more fruits and vegetables?\n   A: You must grasp logistical efficiencies. What does a cow eat? Hay and\n  corn. And what are these? Vegetables. So a steak is nothing more than an\n  efficient mechanism of delivering vegetables to your system. Need grain?\n  Eat chicken. Beef is also a good source of field grass (green leafy\n  vegetable). And a pork chop can give you 100% of your recommended daily\n  allowance of vegetable slop.\n\n   Q: Is beer or wine bad for me?\n   A: Look, it goes to the earlier point about fruits and vegetables. As we\n  all know, scientists divide everything in the world into three categories=\n:\n  animal, mineral, and vegetable. We all know that beer and wine are not\n  animal, and they are not on the periodic table of elements, so that only\n  leaves one thing, right? My advice: Have a burger and a beer and enjoy\n your\n  liquid vegetables.\n\n   Q: How can I calculate my body/fat ratio?\n   A: Well, if you have a body, and you have body fat, your ratio is one to\n  one. If you have two bodies, your ratio is two to one, etc.\n\n    Q: At the gym, a guy asked me to "spot" for him while he did the bench\n  press. If the gas at the point is out of spec on water, the answer is clearly \nno.  We\'re shutting in that supply due to our termination of a waiver of the \ntariff quality spec., not due to force majeure.  We have the discretion to \ngrant or terminate waivers of the tariff in our discretion as prudent \noperators and so long as we don\'t discriminate. The \ncontract requires us to notify ECS by March 1.  Thanks.  DF\n\n\n", 1], ['TW Fuel', 'text/plain', 'This morning I raised a concern regarding TW\'s sale of excess fuel at \ndownstream points.  Here\'s the problem:  the tariff requires shippers to \ntender fuel to us at their receipt points.  With rare exceptions, those \nreceipt points are not at the Cal. border.  Order 636 mandates that pipelines \nunbundle transportation from storage.  It also requires that pipelines that \nmake gas sales do so at the furthest upstream point on their pipeline.  That \nlatter requirement means that if a pipe buys gas at point "x", it should \nresell the gas at point "x" and not haul the gas to point "y" and then sell \nit there as a delivered (i.e., bundled) product.  My concern this morning was \nthat our receipt of fuel gas in the San Juan or Permian and shipment of that \ngas to the Cal. border for sale arguably violates the unbundling requirement \n(because the Cal. border sale is a bundled combination of the sale and the \ntransportation of the gas to the downstream location) or the "furthest \nupstream point" requirement or both.  Susan and my recollection was that when \nECS wanted to receive the Gallup fuel deliveries at  a point other than \nPermian pool, we made them sign a transport contract to move the gas to where \nthey wanted it.  I haven\'t confirmed that recollection but I am recalling \nthat we told Courtney that we couldn\'t just move our fuel gas around \nwhereever we wanted it--we needed someone to pay us to transport it.\n\nIrrespective of what we did with ECS, I think the following is the correct \nway to look at this situation:  We receive fuel at the shippers\' receipt \npoints.  Once we receive it, however, it is no longer "fuel."  It becomes \nline pack until it is burned.   Line pack moves around based on a lot of \nreasons, including shipper imbalances, etc.  It also, obviously, has to move \nto the compressors where it is burned as fuel.   It is our job to  manage \nline pack, and that means we buy line pack at locations where we are short, \nand sell it at locations where we are long.  If we end up long at the Cal. \nborder from time to time, we should sell excess line pack to get line pack \nback to optimal levels.  I wouldn\'t want to get into a pattern where we are \nconsistently buying line pack in the San Juan and Permian and selling line \npack at the Cal. border, but  thats not what we are talking about here.  I \ncan\'t think of anything in the tariff or otherwise that is inconsistent with \nthis interpretation of our authority as operator of the pipeline.  MKM--OK \nwith you?  DF  \n\n', 1], ['Four Corners Pricing', 'text/plain', 'Tino, attached is a spreadsheet with the info I think you need.  I got the \npublication wrong--its "Megawatt Daily" that posts daily prices. We are still discussing it with ECS and \ncan make whatever changes are appropriate.  Note that the letter agreement \nties back to Article 6 of the Compression Services Agreement.  That article, \nyou may recall, is where ECS agreed to create a computerized system that \nwould monitor Continental Divide's electric system utilization and warn when \ntheir system peaks were occurring and then automatically take the compressor \noffline (subject to manual override) so we and ECS could avoid peak period \ndemand charges.  Instead of creating such a system, which apparently turned \nout to be mostly a manual system anyway, ECS is going to pay us a monthly fee \nto monitor CD's system peaks ourselves and decide when we need to get off \nline.  The load management service has to do with operational management of \nthe load we place on CD's electric system, and is not a jurisdictional gas \ntransportation or storage service.  Note that the service goes on for 10 \nyears (as required by the accountants' 10 year amortization rule) and thus \nmay be vulnerable to scrutiny and potential revenue crediting in TW's 2007 \nrate case. He\'s got an \n80mw nameplate simple cycle project (two frame 6 turbines) under development \nin Utah that he started development on a month ago and is projected to go in \nservice on July 1. His Utah site is at the Magnesium Corp. of \nAmerica plant on the Great Salt Lake. Magcorp is an ex-client of mine and I \nknow it is a huge emissions source and has no Nimby issues.  Our compressor \nsites, in contrast, are not major emissions sites but may have some other \nthings in common with this strategy.\n\n3. That \nmeans the power plant emissions are not treated as part of the same emissions \nsource as the host/site. I\'ll try to restate them, and add my initial \nthoughts, so we can all be sure to focus on the correct problems.  \n\nQ 1. Can TW use "negotiated rate" agreements for its new 150 mm/d expansion?  \n\nA.  Yes.  Independence, Guardian, and other new pipeline projects were \ncertificated on the basis of negotiated rate contracts.  The only restriction \nis that we need to always offer cost-based recourse rate service as an \nalternative to negotiated rates.  We hope to use negotiated rate agreements \nfor the entire 150 mm of capacity, but we won\'t know until the contracts are \nexecuted how much of it will be negotiated rate contracts and how much of it \nwill be under recourse rate contracts.  I guess that means that in the cert. \napp., we just tell the commission that we will be 100% at risk and that given \nthe huge interest in the open season, we have no doubts about our ability to \nsell the full 150.  We should also tell the Commission we expect to sell the \ncapacity using negotiated rate contracts or recourse rate contracts or a \ncombination of both.  \n\nQ 2.  Can we give prospective customers a "cafeteria style" menu of options \n(to steal Jeff\'s term), like the following:\n 1.  5 yr. neg. rate deal at a locked in $.60 plus fuel and surcharges (or \nwhatever number we decide on)\n 2.  10 y. neg. rate deal at a locked in $.45 plus fuel and surcharges\n 3.  15 yr. neg rate deal at a locked in $.35 blah blah\n 4 .  15 yr cost based recourse rate plus fuel and surcharges (importantly \nthis option is not locked in and will float with TW\'s actual rate levels and \nfuel retainage percentages)\n\nA.  I think the answer here is "yes."  Whatever options we come up with for \n1, 2, and 3, we will always have to offer 4 as well.  Susan and Steve \nStojic:  please confirm that we have the right to define specific negotiated \nrate options and stick to them.  Otherwise, this negotiated rate approach \ncould get completely unstructured such that we end up with some guys taking \nour specific options and other guys custom tailoring weird variations (like a \n7 yr, 231 day contract at $.51764, for example).  I\'m not sure that would be \na bad thing, but we need to think about it.  We need to be sure we can tell a \ncustomer "no" and make it stick if he tries to mix and match by asking for \nthe 5 yr term and the $.35 rate, for example.  I think we can lay out options \nof our choosing and then enforce a "no substitutions" policy (this is \nsticking with the "cafeteria" theme) but we need to be sure.  \n\nQ.3.  If we can use the "cafeteria options" approach, how much flexibility do \nwe have in structuring the options?  \n\nA:  This one is hard.  We need to be sure that the price and term we choose \nto offer for options 1-3 is solely within our discretion.  We don\'t want to \nbe second guessed by FERC as to whether we should have offered option 1 at \n$.58 instead of $.60.  Susan and Steve: if you guys confirm that we have \ndiscretion in how to structure our negotiated rate options, does that mean we \ncan slant the economics of the negotiated rate options so they are a better \ndeal than the recourse option (for most shippers)?  I.e., could we \ndeliberately  incent shippers to sign on for the short term deals--i.e., by \noffering options 1-3 at $.55, $.45 and $.40 instead of the $.60, $.45, and \n$.35 shown above.  I suspect that is what Guardian and the other pipes did to \nobtain 100% subscription under neg. rate deals.            \n\nQ.4.  How do we allocate capacity to customers if demand exceeds supply???\n\nA.  Ideally, we\'d be able to allocate the 150 to the guys who want to buy it \nthe way we\'d prefer to sell it.  Under the above example, assuming Stan, \nDanny and Steve decide short term deals are better, what if we get 100 mm/d \nof offers on each of the 4 rate/term options described above.  That\'s 400 \nmm/d of demand for a 150 mm/d project.  Can we sell 100 to the guys who want \noption 1 ($.60/5 yrs) and the remaining 50 to the 10 yr/$.45 guys?  That \nreally hoses the recourse bidders.  Do we have to cover the recourse demand \nfirst and then allocate the remaining capacity pro rata to everyone else?  \nPro rata to everyone?  Under the rule that negotiated rate bids have to be \ndeemed to be at max rate for purposes of allocation, pro rata to everyone may \nbe the right answer.  Or at least its the answer until we\'ve filled the \nrecourse rate guys\' orders, then we can give the remaining capacity to the \nneg. rate guys whose bids we value most highly (using some objective \nnondiscriminatory calculation of course).   Ugh. \n\nSusan and Steve--please take a crack at questions 2-4.  I think 1 is answered \nalready.  I haven\'t done any research yet, so maybe these questions are \neasier than they currently seem to me.  Get me and MKM on the phone at your \nconvenience to discuss. We have the option \non new projects to go with the existing max tariff rate or a new \nincrementally designed rate.  We are going with the existing tariff rate on \nRedRock.  Fine, but that makes the existing rate the recourse rate for all \npurposes.  FERC\'s logic will be that TW could sell all of the RedRock \ncapacity at recourse rates (currently $.38) and never suffer a revenue \nshortfall even if future rate cases reduce TW\'s overall rates, because the \ncosts of all TW\'s facilities--including the new project--will be considered \nin the next rate case.  Think about it--our rates will only go down in the \nfuture if the ENTIRE cost of service goes down.  We\'d never "lose money" on \nRedRock, but we might not make as much as we could have made with an 15 year \nfixed $.38 negotiated rate.\n\nThere is another  approach.
